LTWL 19A-B-C.name: Introduction to the Ancient Greeks and Romans

LTWL 4A-C-D-F-M.class_description: A study of modern culture and of the way it is expressed and understood in novels, stories, and films. A study of modern culture and of the way it is expressed and understood in novels, stories, and films. The sequence aims at an understanding of relationship between the narrative arts and society in the twentieth century, with the individual quarters treating fiction and film of the following language groups. 4A French,  4C Asian, 4D Italian, 4M multiple national literatures and film, 4F Spanish.
LTWL 4A-C-D-F-M.name: Film and Fiction in Twentieth-Century Societies

LTWL 500.class_description: Consideration of pedagogical methods appropriate to undergraduate teaching in literature courses under the supervision of instructor of course. Consideration of pedagogical methods appropriate to undergraduate teaching in literature courses under the supervision of instructor of course. Doctoral students in literature are required to participate in undergraduate teaching for a minimum of twelve units (two to four units per quarter) prior to completion of the PhD degree.
LTWL 500.name: Apprentice Teaching in Literature

LTWL 87.class_description: The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Freshman Seminars are offered in all campus departments and undergraduate colleges, and topics vary from quarter to quarter. Enrollment is limited to fifteen to twenty students, with preference given to entering freshmen.
LTWL 87.name: Freshman Seminar

LTWR 100.class_description: A workshop for students with some experience and special interest in writing fiction. A workshop for students with some experience and special interest in writing fiction. This workshop is designed to encourage regular writing in the short forms of prose fiction and to permit students to experiment with various forms. There will be discussion of student work, together with analysis and discussion of representative examples of short fiction from the present and previous ages. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 100.name: Short Fiction Workshop

LTWR 101.class_description: A workshop for students with interest in writing fiction in Spanish. A workshop for students with interest in writing fiction in Spanish. Includes discussion of student work, together with analysis and discussion of representative examples of short fiction from the present and previous ages. A working knowledge of Spanish is required. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 101.name: Writing Fiction in Spanish
LTWR 101.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: LTWR 8A; LTSP 50A or 50B or 50C; department approval.

LTWR 102.class_description: A workshop for students with some experience and special interest in writing poetry. A workshop for students with some experience and special interest in writing poetry. This workshop is designed to encourage regular writing of poetry. There will be discussion of student work, together with analysis and discussion of representative examples of poetry from the present and previous ages. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 102.name: Poetry Workshop

LTWR 103.class_description: This workshop includes instruction on using software and writing basic computer code to allow students to create innovative web-based works that experiment with poetic form, draw on rich media resources, and provide more accessibility and interactivity for public audiences. This workshop includes instruction on using software and writing basic computer code to allow students to create innovative web-based works that experiment with poetic form, draw on rich media resources, and provide more accessibility and interactivity for public audiences. May be taken up to three times for credit.
LTWR 103.name: Digital Poetics Workshop

LTWR 104A.class_description: A two-quarter workshop for fiction writers ready to explore a longer form, and committed to developing a single piece over the course of two consecutive quarters. A two-quarter workshop for fiction writers ready to explore a longer form, and committed to developing a single piece over the course of two consecutive quarters. In addition to analyzing student work, we will read and discuss a wide range of published novellas. Two-quarter sequence; students must complete LTWR 104A and LTWR 104B in order to receive final grade in both courses.
LTWR 104A.name: The Novella I

LTWR 104B.class_description: A continuation of LTWR 104A in which fiction writers complete the novella manuscripts they began during the previous quarter. A continuation of LTWR 104A in which fiction writers complete the novella manuscripts they began during the previous quarter. Each student will produce a novella of at least fifty revised pages by the end of the quarter. We will continue to read and discuss published novellas with a particular emphasis on narrative strategy, structure, and revision. Two-quarter sequence; students must complete LTWR 104A and LTWR 104B in order to receive final grade in both courses.
LTWR 104B.name: The Novella II

LTWR 106.class_description: In this workshop, students will practice skills of narration, characterization, and style with particular attention to the demands of nonrealistic genres, especially the challenge of suspending disbelief in fictional environments that defy conventional logic. In this workshop, students will practice skills of narration, characterization, and style with particular attention to the demands of nonrealistic genres, especially the challenge of suspending disbelief in fictional environments that defy conventional logic. Readings and lectures will accompany writing exercises. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 106.name: Science Fiction, Fantasy, and Irrealism Workshop

LTWR 110.class_description: A workshop designed to encourage writing of original screenplays and adaptations. A workshop designed to encourage writing of original screenplays and adaptations. There will be discussion of study work, together with analysis of discussion of representative examples of screen writing. May be taken up to three times for credit.
LTWR 110.name: Screen Writing

LTWR 113.class_description: This course is an introduction to modes of writing from other cultural systems vastly different from the cultural-aesthetic assumptions of Anglo American writing. This course is an introduction to modes of writing from other cultural systems vastly different from the cultural-aesthetic assumptions of Anglo American writing. While disclosing the limitations of the English language, this course attempts to provide new language strategies for students. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 113.name: Intercultural Writing Workshop

LTWR 114.class_description: From illuminated manuscripts to digital literature, from alphabets to concrete poems, from artists’ books to comics, this course explores the histories and techniques of combinatory image/word literary arts. From illuminated manuscripts to digital literature, from alphabets to concrete poems, from artists’ books to comics, this course explores the histories and techniques of combinatory image/word literary arts. The course may emphasize specific movements or genres. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 114.name: Graphic Texts Workshop
LTWR 114.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: LTWR 8A or 8B or 8C; department approval.

LTWR 115.class_description: This workshop explores writing for which the traditional generic distinctions of prose/poetry, fiction/documentary, narrative/discourse do not apply. This workshop explores writing for which the traditional generic distinctions of prose/poetry, fiction/documentary, narrative/discourse do not apply. Students taking this course will be asked to challenge the boundaries of literature to discover new forms and modes of expression. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 115.name: Experimental Writing Workshop

LTWR 119.class_description: A workshop and survey of experimental approaches to the writing and production of performance works in a range of literary genres. A workshop and survey of experimental approaches to the writing and production of performance works in a range of literary genres. Emphasis will be placed on the integration of written texts with nonverbal elements from the visual arts, theatre, and music.
LTWR 119.name: Writing for Performance
LTWR 119.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: LTWR 8A or 8B, to be determined by quarterly offerings of LTWR 119; department approval.

LTWR 120.class_description: A workshop designed to encourage regular writing of all forms of personal experience narrative, including journals, autobiography, firsthand biography, and firsthand chronicle. A workshop designed to encourage regular writing of all forms of personal experience narrative, including journals, autobiography, firsthand biography, and firsthand chronicle. Instructor and students will discuss student work as well as published personal narratives. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 120.name: Personal Narrative Workshop

LTWR 121.class_description: Workshop focusing on the review, the op-ed piece, the column, the blurb, the profile, the interview, and “content-providing” for websites. Workshop focusing on the review, the op-ed piece, the column, the blurb, the profile, the interview, and “content-providing” for websites. We’ll examine current examples of media writing; students will produce a body of work and critique one another’s productions. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 121.name: Media Writing Workshop

LTWR 122.class_description: A workshop in writing about science for the public. A workshop in writing about science for the public. Students will study and then construct metaphors or analogues that introduce readers to scientific perplexities. Completion of LTWR 8A, 8B, or 8C highly recommended. May be repeated for credit three times.
LTWR 122.name: Writing for the Sciences Workshop

LTWR 126.class_description: A writing, reading, and critical-thinking workshop designed to produce nonfiction pieces that fall outside the limits of the essay form. A writing, reading, and critical-thinking workshop designed to produce nonfiction pieces that fall outside the limits of the essay form. Included are travel narratives, memoir, and information-based writing that transform their own materials into compelling literature. May be repeated for credit three times.
LTWR 126.name: Creative Nonfiction Workshop

LTWR 129.class_description: Workshop designed to critique and engage the means of distributing literature within culture. Workshop designed to critique and engage the means of distributing literature within culture. Publishing from “zine” through mainstream publication; web publishings; readings and “slams”; publicity and funding; colloquia with writers; politics and literature; and the uses of performance and media. May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 129.name: Distributing Literature Workshop
LTWR 129.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: LTWR 100, LTWR 102, or LTWR 120; department approval.

LTWR 140.class_description: A review of the history of the development of alphabets and writing systems. A review of the history of the development of alphabets and writing systems. Survey of the rise of literacy since the fifteenth century and analysis of continuing literacy problems in developed and developing countries..
LTWR 140.name: History of Writing

LTWR 143.class_description: A close look at sentence-level features of written discourse–stylistics and sentence grammars. A close look at sentence-level features of written discourse–stylistics and sentence grammars. Students will review recent research on these topics and experiment in their own writing with various stylistic and syntactic options.
LTWR 143.name: Stylistics and Grammar

LTWR 144.class_description: Wide reading in current theory and practice of teaching writing in schools and colleges. Wide reading in current theory and practice of teaching writing in schools and colleges. Careful attention to various models of classroom writing instruction and to different approaches in the individual conference. Students in this course may observe instruction in the UC San Diego college writing programs or tutor freshman students in those programs.
LTWR 144.name: The Teaching of Writing

LTWR 148.class_description: Hybrid workshop offering writing students a working knowledge of literary theory while exposing literature students to practical techniques from poetry, fiction, and nonfiction to refresh their writing of theoretical nonfiction texts. Hybrid workshop offering writing students a working knowledge of literary theory while exposing literature students to practical techniques from poetry, fiction, and nonfiction to refresh their writing of theoretical nonfiction texts. Discussion of student work and published work.
LTWR 148.name: Theory for Writers/Writing for Theory

LTWR 194.class_description: An advanced seminar open to all writing majors in their senior year. An advanced seminar open to all writing majors in their senior year. Required for those interested in the Honors Program. It offers an integrative experience by considering key facets of the discipline and profession, including relationships between aesthetics/culture and politics, genre writing, craft/technique, literary theories/theories of writing, and distribution/publication.
LTWR 194.name: Capstone Course for Writing Majors

LTWR 195.class_description: Undergraduate instruction assistance. Undergraduate instruction assistance. A student will 1) assist TA in editing students’ writing for LTWR 8A-B-C during class and outside of class; and 2) prepare a paper and report for the professor at the end of the quarter. May be taken for credit up to two times.
LTWR 195.name: Apprentice Teaching

LTWR 196.class_description: Senior thesis research and writing for students who have been accepted for the Literature Honors Program and who have completed LTWL 191. Senior thesis research and writing for students who have been accepted for the Literature Honors Program and who have completed LTWL 191. Oral exam.
LTWR 196.name: Honors Thesis

LTWR 198.class_description: Directed group study in areas of writing not normally covered in courses. Directed group study in areas of writing not normally covered in courses. (P/NP grades only.  Repeatable for credit when areas of study vary.
LTWR 198.name: Directed Group Study

LTWR 199.class_description: Tutorial; individual guidance in areas of writing not normally covered in courses. Tutorial; individual guidance in areas of writing not normally covered in courses. (P/NP grades only.  May be taken for credit three times.
LTWR 199.name: Special Studies
LTWR 199.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing and department approval.

LTWR 215.class_description: In the generative workshop, writers create intergenre works and practice unconventional workshopping techniques that function less as editorial roundtables and more as discussions of the relationships between aesthetics and culture. In the generative workshop, writers create intergenre works and practice unconventional workshopping techniques that function less as editorial roundtables and more as discussions of the relationships between aesthetics and culture.
LTWR 215.name: Cross-Genre Workshop

LTWR 220.class_description: This seminar will be organized around any of various topic areas relating to writing (fiction, poetry, cross-genre, theory). This seminar will be organized around any of various topic areas relating to writing (fiction, poetry, cross-genre, theory). Topics might focus on a genre (film, popular novel, theatre) or on the transformations of a theme or metaphor (nation, femininity, the uncanny). S/U grades only. May be taken for credit three times as content varies.
LTWR 220.name: Topics in Writing
LTWR 220.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: admission to the MFA in writing, major code LT84.

LTWR 298.class_description: This course may be designed according to an individual student’s needs when seminar offerings do not cover subjects, genres, or authors of interest. This course may be designed according to an individual student’s needs when seminar offerings do not cover subjects, genres, or authors of interest. May be applied toward the guided research or graduate seminar in literature requirement of the MFA program. Repeatable for credit.
LTWR 298.name: Directed Studies: Writing Course

LTWR 8A.class_description: Study of fiction in both theory and practice. Study of fiction in both theory and practice. Narrative technique studied in terms of subjectivity and atmosphere, description, dialogue, and the editing process will be introduced through readings from the history of the novel and short story. Students are required to attend at least three New Writing Series readings during the quarter.
LTWR 8A.name: Writing Fiction
LTWR 8A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: CAT 2 and 3 or DOC 2 and 3 or HUM 1 and 2 or MCWP 40 and 50 or MMW 12 and 13 or WARR 11A-B or WCWP 10A-B.

LTWR 8B.class_description: Study and practice of poetry as artistic and communal expression. Study and practice of poetry as artistic and communal expression. Techniques of composition (traditional forms, avant garde techniques, dramatic monologue, performance poetry, and new genre) studied through written and spoken examples of poetry. Students are required to attend at least three New Writing Series readings during the quarter.
LTWR 8B.name: Writing Poetry
LTWR 8B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: CAT 2 and 3 or DOC 2 and 3 or HUM 1 and 2 or MCWP 40 and 50 or MMW 12 and 13 or WARR 11A-B or WCWP 10A-B.

LTWR 8C.class_description: Study of nonfictional prose in terms of genre and craft. Study of nonfictional prose in terms of genre and craft. Techniques of composition (journalism, essay, letters, reviews) will be studied through written examples of the genre.
LTWR 8C.name: Writing Nonfiction
LTWR 8C.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: CAT 2 and 3 or DOC 2 and 3 or HUM 1 and 2 or MCWP 40 and 50 or MMW 12 and 13 or WARR 11A-B or WCWP 10A-B. Completion of college writing requirement.

MAE 02.class_description: An introduction to topics in aeronautical and astronautical engineering including aerodynamics, propulsion, flight mechanics, structures, materials, orbital mechanics, design, mission planning, and environments. An introduction to topics in aeronautical and astronautical engineering including aerodynamics, propulsion, flight mechanics, structures, materials, orbital mechanics, design, mission planning, and environments. General topics include historical background, career opportunities, engineering ethics, and professionalism.
MAE 02.name: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering

MAE 03.class_description: Introduction to design process through a hands-on design project performed in teams. Introduction to design process through a hands-on design project performed in teams. Topics include problem identification, concept generation, project management, risk reduction. Engineering graphics and communication skills are introduced in the areas of: Computer-Aided Design (CAD), hand sketching, and technical communication. Program or materials fees may apply.
MAE 03.name: Introduction to Engineering Graphics and Design
MAE 03.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: Phys 2A or 4A. Enrollment restricted to BE 25, MC 27, MC 28, and MC 29 majors only.

MAE 05.class_description: Introductory course for nonengineering majors. Introductory course for nonengineering majors. Use of computers in solving problems; applications from life sciences, physical sciences, and engineering. Students run existing computer programs and complete some programming in BASIC.
MAE 05.name: Quantitative Computer Skills

MAE 07.class_description: (Cross-listed with SE 7. (Cross-listed with SE 7.  Spatial visualization is the ability to manipulate 2-D and 3-D shapes in one’s mind. In this course, students will perform exercises that increase their spatial visualization skills.
MAE 07.name: Spatial Visualization

MAE 08.class_description: Computer programming in Matlab with elementary numerical analysis of engineering problems. Computer programming in Matlab with elementary numerical analysis of engineering problems. Arithmetic and logical operations, arrays, graphical presentation of computations, symbolic mathematics, solutions of equations, and introduction to data structures.
MAE 08.name: Matlab Programming for Engineering Analysis
MAE 08.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: Math 20A and 20B or consent of instructor.

MAE 101A.class_description: Fluid statics; fluid kinematics; integral and differential forms of the conservation laws for mass, momentum, and energy; Bernoulli equation; potential flows; dimensional analysis and similitude. Fluid statics; fluid kinematics; integral and differential forms of the conservation laws for mass, momentum, and energy; Bernoulli equation; potential flows; dimensional analysis and similitude.
MAE 101A.name: Introductory Fluid Mechanics
MAE 101A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: Phys 2A, Math 20D or 21D and Math 20E, or consent of instructor. Enrollment restricted to engineering majors only.

MAE 101B.class_description:
Laminar and turbulent flow. Laminar and turbulent flow. Pipe flow including
				  friction factor. Boundary layers, separation, drag, and lift. Compressible
			    flow including shock waves.
MAE 101B.name: Advanced Fluid Mechanics
MAE 101B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites:  MAE 101A or CENG 101A or CENG 103A, and MAE 110A or CENG 102, or consent of instructor.

MAE 101C.class_description:
Extension of fluid mechanics in MAE 101A–B
				  to viscous, heat-conducting flows. Extension of fluid mechanics in MAE 101A–B
				  to viscous, heat-conducting flows. Application of the energy
				  conservation equation to heat transfer in ducts and external
				  boundary layers. Heat conduction and radiation transfer. Heat transfer
				  coefficients in forced and free convection. Design applications.
MAE 101C.name: Heat Transfer
MAE 101C.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: MAE			    101A or CENG 101A or CENG 103A, MAE 101B, and MAE 105, or consent of instructor.

MAE 101D.class_description: Course builds on the MAE fluids sequence, offering more advanced concepts in conduction, convection, radiation, and heat exchanger design. Course builds on the MAE fluids sequence, offering more advanced concepts in conduction, convection, radiation, and heat exchanger design. This course covers numerical methods in conduction, boiling, condensation and evaporation analysis, natural and turbulent convection, spectral and directional radiative transfer, heatpipes, thermal design of spacecraft, heat exchanger analysis and design.
MAE 101D.name: Intermediate Heat Transfer
MAE 101D.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing and MAE 101C, or consent of instructor.

MAE 104.class_description:
Basic relations describing flow field around
				  wings and bodies at subsonic and supersonic speed. Basic relations describing flow field around
				  wings and bodies at subsonic and supersonic speed. Thin-wing
				  theory. Slender-body theory. Formulation of theories for evaluating forces
				  and moments on airplane geometries. Application to the design of high-speed
				  aircraft.
MAE 104.name: Aerodynamics
MAE 104.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: grades of C– or better in MAE 101A and 101B, or consent of instructor. Enrollment restricted to MC 25, MC 27, MC 28, and SE 27 majors only.

MAE 105.class_description:
Fourier series, Sturm Liouville theory, elementary
				  partial differential equations, integral transforms with applications to
				  problems in vibration, wave motion, and heat conduction. Fourier series, Sturm Liouville theory, elementary
				  partial differential equations, integral transforms with applications to
				  problems in vibration, wave motion, and heat conduction.
MAE 105.name: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
MAE 105.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: grades of C– or better in Phys 2A and B, and Math 20D or 21D. Enrollment restricted to engineering majors only.

MAE 107.class_description: Introduction to scientific computing and algorithms; iterative methods, systems of linear equations with applications; nonlinear algebraic equations; function interpolation and differentiation and optimal procedures; data fitting and least-squares; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations. Introduction to scientific computing and algorithms; iterative methods, systems of linear equations with applications; nonlinear algebraic equations; function interpolation and differentiation and optimal procedures; data fitting and least-squares; numerical solution of ordinary differential equations.
MAE 107.name: Computational Methods in Engineering
MAE 107.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: MAE 8 or 9, and Math 18 or 20F or 31AH. Enrollment restricted to engineering majors only.

MAE 108.class_description:
Probability theory, conditional probability, Bayes theorem,
                  random variables, densities, expected values, characteristic
                  functions, central limit theorem. Probability theory, conditional probability, Bayes theorem,
                  random variables, densities, expected values, characteristic
                  functions, central limit theorem. Engineering reliability,
                  elements of estimation, random sampling, sampling distributions,
                  hypothesis testing, confidence intervals. Curve fitting and
data analysis. Students cannot receive credit for MAE 108 and ECE 109, Econ 120A, Math 180A, Math 183, Math 186, or SE 125.

Compressible flow, thermodynamics, and combustion
				  relevant to aircraft and space vehicle propulsion. Compressible flow, thermodynamics, and combustion
				  relevant to aircraft and space vehicle propulsion. Analysis
				  and design of components for gas turbines, including turbines, inlets,

(Cross-listed with Physics 151. (Cross-listed with Physics 151.  Particle

Basic principles of solar radiation—diffuse and direct radiation; elementary solar energy engineering—solar thermal and solar photovoltaic; basic principles of wind dynamics—hydrodynamic laws, wind intermittency, Betz’s law; elementary wind energy engineering; solar and wind energy perspectives; operating the California power grid with 33 percent renewable energy sources. (Cross-listed with ESYS 103. (Cross-listed with ESYS 103.  This course

Energy and momentum methods. Impulsive motion and impact. Systems of particles. Kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in 2-D. Introduction to 3-D dynamics of rigid bodies. (Cross-listed with SE 101C. (Cross-listed with SE 101C.  Free and forced

				  excited vibrations. Vibrations under general loading conditions. Vibrating
				  systems with multiple degrees of freedom. Modal analysis with application

				  to the mechanical response of machine and structural elements.

				  to the mechanical response of machine and structural elements.

				  plane stress and plane strain; stress concentrations; fracture mechanics.
