NANO 260.unrec_prereqs: Theory, simulation, and reactor design. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 261.class_description: Examines the role nanotechnology will play in addressing the many scientific and engineering challenges for new energy production.      Examines the role nanotechnology will play in addressing the many scientific and engineering challenges for new energy production.
NANO 261.name: Nanoscale Energy Technology
NANO 261.unrec_prereqs: Topics include nanotechnology’s role in improving photovoltaics, fuel-cells, batteries, energy transmission, and conversion of renewable (green) and nonrenewable sources. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 262.class_description: This course illustrates how the ability to tailor the properties of nanomaterials can be used for designing powerful sensing and biosensing devices. This course illustrates how the ability to tailor the properties of nanomaterials can be used for designing powerful sensing and biosensing devices.
NANO 262.name: Nanosensors
NANO 262.unrec_prereqs: Nanosensors based on metal nanoparticles, semiconductor nanowires and nanocrystals, and carbon nanotubes will be covered. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 263.class_description: The basis of magnetism: classical and quantum mechanical points of view. The basis of magnetism: classical and quantum mechanical points of view. Introduction to thin film and nanomagnetism, including interfacial magnetism, coupling and magneto-transport.
NANO 263.name: Magnetic Nanodevices
NANO 263.unrec_prereqs: Application of nanomagnetism in devices including magnetic recording, MRAM, magnetic processing, and biomedical engineering. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 264.class_description: Course covers concept in nano and solid-state chemistry for graduate students, with the objective of understanding nanomaterials from a chemical perspective. Course covers concept in nano and solid-state chemistry for graduate students, with the objective of understanding nanomaterials from a chemical perspective. Topics include descriptive crystal chemistry, structure determination, free electron gas and dimensional solids, tight-binding approximation, band structure. Recommended preparation: Background equivalent to NANO 203..
NANO 264.name: Solid-State and Nanochemistry

NANO 265.class_description: The thermodynamics and statistical mechanics of solids. The thermodynamics and statistical mechanics of solids. Basic concepts, equilibrium properties of alloy systems, thermodynamic information from phase diagrams, surfaces and interfaces, crystalline defects.
NANO 265.name: Thermodynamics of Solids
NANO 265.unrec_prereqs: Cross-listed with MATS 201A, MAE 271A and ECE 238A. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 266.class_description: Application of quantum mechanical modeling methods (both solid state and computational chemistry) in the study of materials and nanostructures; density functional theory (DFT) and approximations; Hartree-Fock and beyond HF approximations; hybrid density functional theory; beyond DFT (GW, TDDFT); ab initio molecular dynamics; materials properties (mechanical, electrochemical, electronic, transport, nano-scale effects on properties) from quantum mechanical simulations; high-throughput computation. Prerequisites: consent of instructor..
NANO 266.name: Quantum Mechanical Modeling of Materials and Nanostructures
NANO 266.unrec_prereqs: Application of quantum mechanical modeling methods (both solid state and computational chemistry) in the study of materials and nanostructures; density functional theory (DFT) and approximations; Hartree-Fock and beyond HF approximations; hybrid density functional theory; beyond DFT (GW, TDDFT); ab initio molecular dynamics; materials properties (mechanical, electrochemical, electronic, transport, nano-scale effects on properties) from quantum mechanical simulations; high-throughput computation. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 267.class_description: (Cross-listed with Chem 267. (Cross-listed with Chem 267.  This course explores the potential impacts of nanoscience and nanotechnology on environmental processes and human health as well as the sustainable design, development, and use of nanotechnologies. The course addresses questions and issues arising from the expected increases in the development of nanotechnology-based consumer products and their potential effects on the environment. Students may not receive credit for Chem 267 and NANO 267..
NANO 267.name: Environmental Nanotechnology, Sustainable Nanotechnology, and Nanotoxicity

NANO 268.class_description: Introduction to DNA nanotechnology. Introduction to DNA nanotechnology. Topics include basic design principles for DNA nano structures and DNA origami, DNA nano motors, computing, and the use of DNA nanotechnology in organizing other materials, nano fabrication, biosensing, and drug delivery..
NANO 268.name: DNA Nanotechnology

NANO 269.class_description: Fundamentals of photovoltaic energy conversion; limiting efficiencies, loss mechanisms. Fundamentals of photovoltaic energy conversion; limiting efficiencies, loss mechanisms. Nanoscale effects in semiconductor, thin film, and organic photovoltaics. Emphasis on emerging nanotechnologies including nanowires, heterostructures, hybrid materials, quantum dots, transparent conducting materials, and plasmonics..
NANO 269.name: Engineering Solar Cells at the Nanoscale

NANO 271.class_description: This course will introduce a background in optics and photonics for nanoscale materials and devices and explore light-matter interactions on the nanoscale. This course will introduce a background in optics and photonics for nanoscale materials and devices and explore light-matter interactions on the nanoscale. Fundamentals of light absorption, emission, lasing, and waveguiding in nanoscale structures, optical resonances in metallic (plasmonic) and semiconductor (excitonic) nanomaterials..
NANO 271.name: Nanophotonics

NANO 272.class_description: General overview of flexible/stretchable electronic devices, with a focus on the enabling nanomaterials and structures that lead to the tolerance to extreme physical deformations. General overview of flexible/stretchable electronic devices, with a focus on the enabling nanomaterials and structures that lead to the tolerance to extreme physical deformations. Relevant nanofabrication techniques and manufacturing approaches will also be included..
NANO 272.name: Soft Electronics

NANO 275.class_description: Overview of of graphene and other 2-D materials fundamental properties, applications, and experimental practice. Overview of of graphene and other 2-D materials fundamental properties, applications, and experimental practice. Theory covers band structure, Dirac cone, mobility, and Fermi level tuning. Applications cover electronics and optoelectronics. Lab sessions include graphene and other 2-D materials manipulation and measurement.  .
NANO 275.name: Two-Dimensional Materials: Properties, Applications, and Practice

NANO 279.class_description: Electrochemistry and electrochemical engineering for energy applications. Electrochemistry and electrochemical engineering for energy applications. Thermodynamics and kinetics of electrochemical reactions; fundamental principles of batteries, super capacitors, fuel cells, and electrochemical synthesis systems; electrochemical analysis of these systems, engineering design considerations, and modeling. Practical device design and fabrication will be covered in greater detail..
NANO 279.name: Advanced Electrochemical Energy Engineering

NANO 280.class_description: This course will cover fundamental concepts and laboratory techniques to study the chemical and physical properties of colloids and nanoparticles. This course will cover fundamental concepts and laboratory techniques to study the chemical and physical properties of colloids and nanoparticles. Topics covered include: colloid and surface forces, Brownian motion, aggregation, steric stabilization, optical characterization techniques, and self-assembly. Recent developments in colloids and nanotechnology will be discussed throughout the course..
NANO 280.name: Colloids and Nanoparticles

NANO 296.class_description: Independent reading or research on a problem as arranged by a faculty member. Independent reading or research on a problem as arranged by a faculty member.
NANO 296.name: Independent Study in NanoEngineering
NANO 296.unrec_prereqs: Must be taken for a letter grade only. Prerequisites: consent of instructor.

NANO 299.class_description: Graduate research in NanoEngineering. Graduate research in NanoEngineering. S/U grades only. May be taken for credit four times for a maximum of twelve units.
NANO 299.name: Graduate Research in NanoEngineering

NANO 4.class_description: Introduction to NanoEngineering lab-based skills. Introduction to NanoEngineering lab-based skills. Hands-on training and experimentation with nanofabrication techniques, integration, and analytical tools. This class is for NANO majors who are incoming freshmen, to be taken their first year. This class is for NanoEngineering majors who are incoming freshmen, to be taken their first year.
NANO 4.name: Experience NanoEngineering

NEU 199.class_description: Laboratory research under the supervision of individual members of the faculty of the neurosciences department in one or a combination of neurosciences disciplines, e.g., neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neurochemistry, neuropharmacology. Laboratory research under the supervision of individual members of the faculty of the neurosciences department in one or a combination of neurosciences disciplines, e.g., neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neurochemistry, neuropharmacology. (P/NP grades only.  (F,W,S) .
NEU 199.name: Independent Research

NEU 200A-B-C.class_description: These courses are designed for graduate students in the neurosciences and other departments that are part of the interdisciplinary program (i.e., Biology, Cog Sci, Psychology). These courses are designed for graduate students in the neurosciences and other departments that are part of the interdisciplinary program (i.e., Biology, Cog Sci, Psychology). These courses have been designed to cover as much basic neuroscience as possible in three quarters of study. It will combine two three-hour meetings each week with a 1.5 hour lecture and a 1.5 hour discussion of papers. These will be required courses for all first-year neurosciences graduate students. Biology will cross-list courses under Biology headings, making it a requirement of first-year Biology graduate students.
NEU 200A-B-C.name: Basic Neuroscience
NEU 200A-B-C.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate student or consent of instructor. (F,W,S)

NEU 210.class_description: For incoming doctoral students in neurobiology, computational neurosciences, and neurosciences. For incoming doctoral students in neurobiology, computational neurosciences, and neurosciences. During the first two weeks in September, students commit to ten to fifteen hours per day in lectures and laboratories in electrophysiology, cellular anatomy, molecular biology, optical imaging, and computational neurobiology. Students also attend weekly seminars during fall quarter.
NEU 210.name: Neurobiology Boot Camp
NEU 210.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing only. For students in the following major codes: BI77, BI79, NE75, NE78.

NEU 221.class_description: Specialized advanced topic areas in neurosciences will be addressed in an interactive seminar course format. Specialized advanced topic areas in neurosciences will be addressed in an interactive seminar course format. A different specific topic will be considered each quarter as announced in advance. Students will each present an aspect of the topic area and participate in discussions.
NEU 221.name: Advanced Topics in Neurosciences
NEU 221.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate student or consent of instructor. (F,W,S)

NEU 225.class_description: This is a practical course designed to emphasize the relationships between experimental design, statistical methods, and biomedical research. This is a practical course designed to emphasize the relationships between experimental design, statistical methods, and biomedical research. The assumptions behind the statistical tests, their appropriate use, and examples of misuse will be discussed.
NEU 225.name: Statistical Methods and Experimental Design
NEU 225.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: registered student in SOM graduate program or approval of instructor.

NEU 241.class_description: This course will cover “ethical” issues in academia, including dishonesty, plagiarism, attribution, sexual misconduct, etc. This course will cover “ethical” issues in academia, including dishonesty, plagiarism, attribution, sexual misconduct, etc. We will also discuss “survival” issues, including job hunting, grant preparation, journal reviews, writing letters of recommendation, mentoring, etc. (W) .
NEU 241.name: Ethics and Survival Skills in Academia

NEU 243.class_description: Psychological processes including attention, perception, and memory will be studied in connection with event-related potentials of the human brain. Psychological processes including attention, perception, and memory will be studied in connection with event-related potentials of the human brain. The interrelations among psychological and physiological events will be explored in order to arrive at unified concepts of human information processing.
NEU 243.name: Physiological Basis of Human Information
NEU 243.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: Neurosci 238 or Psych. 231, and consent of instructor. (S/U grades only. (F)

NEU 259.class_description: This course is to introduce graduate students in the neurosciences to research methods used in electron microscopy (EM) through one hour of formal lecture, one hour of seminar, three hours of demonstration, and three hours of supervised laboratory work per week. This course is to introduce graduate students in the neurosciences to research methods used in electron microscopy (EM) through one hour of formal lecture, one hour of seminar, three hours of demonstration, and three hours of supervised laboratory work per week. Students will become familiar with sectioning EM, scanning EM, and freeze-fracture EM.
NEU 259.name: Workshop in Electron Microscopy
NEU 259.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate-student standing in neurosciences doctoral program and consent of instructor. Enrollment limited. (S/U grades only. (F)

NEU 260.class_description: Students will review basic principles of light and electron microscopy and learn a variety of basic and advanced microscopy methods through lecture and hands-on training. Students will review basic principles of light and electron microscopy and learn a variety of basic and advanced microscopy methods through lecture and hands-on training. Each student will have his or her own project. Additional supervised instrument time is available.
NEU 260.name: Light and Electron Microscopy of Cells and Tissue

NEU 265.class_description: Anatomical and pharmacological substrates activated following tissue or nerve injury will be discussed. Anatomical and pharmacological substrates activated following tissue or nerve injury will be discussed. Changes in afferents and spinal cord, including increased expressions of channels and receptors, during chronic pain states will be emphasized. Clinical relevance and treatment will be included. (S/U grades only.  (F).
NEU 265.name: Mechanisms of Pain

NEU 266.class_description: Course focuses on developmental processes during formation of neural circuits. Course focuses on developmental processes during formation of neural circuits. Molecular, genetic, cellular mechanisms controlling neurogenesis, neuronal differentiation, positioning (migration), axon/dendrite patterning, and synapse formation will be discussed. Role of neural activity shaping circuit formation will be explored.
NEU 266.name: Development of Neural Circuits
NEU 266.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing only. For students in the following major codes: NE75, NE78, BI77, BI79, or consent of instructor.

NEU 268.class_description: Molecular and cellular approaches to the study of the nervous system are advancing neurobiology at an increasingly rapid pace. Molecular and cellular approaches to the study of the nervous system are advancing neurobiology at an increasingly rapid pace. This graduate-level course will address the latest molecular advances in the areas of: 1) synapse formation, neurotransmitter release, and neurotransmitter receptors; 2) nerve growth factors, their receptors, and neuronal apoptosis; 3) transcriptional regulation in the brain and peripheral nervous system; 4) cell culture, transgenic, and knock-out mouse model systems; 5) the molecular bases of genetic, psychiatric, and degenerative diseases of the nervous system; and 6) the current molecular knowledge of vision, sensory transduction, circadian rhythms, learning, memory, and behavior..
NEU 268.name: Molecular and Cellular Neurobiology

NEU 270A.class_description: This course will blend research and clinical perspectives to allow comprehensive learning of CNS diseases. This course will blend research and clinical perspectives to allow comprehensive learning of CNS diseases. For each two-week disease block, students will read, present, and discuss current research publications which will be paired with a lecture by a research scientist who will describe the major features of each disorder, hypothesis being explored, and the state of therapeutics. The following session will involve a physician presenting an adult patient with the condition, and students will have the opportunity to ask questions of both the physician and the patient. Priority enrollment given to PhD and MD students. MS and undergraduate enrollment permission to be granted by the instructor..
NEU 270A.name: Neurobiology of Disease: Mechanisms of Neurodegeneration

NEU 270B.class_description: This course will blend research and clinical perspectives to allow comprehensive learning of CNS neurodevelopmental disorders. This course will blend research and clinical perspectives to allow comprehensive learning of CNS neurodevelopmental disorders. For each two-week block, students will read, present, and discuss current research publications which will be paired with a lecture by a research scientist who will describe the major features of each disorder, hypothesis being explored, and the state of therapeutics. The following session will involve a physician presenting an adult patient with the condition, and students will have the opportunity to ask questions of both the physician and the patient. Priority enrollment given to PhD and MD students. MS and undergraduate enrollment permission to be granted by the instructor..
NEU 270B.name: Neurobiology of Disease: Neurodevelopmental Disorders

NEU 276.class_description: Neurosciences group faculty members and graduate students will present and discuss ongoing research. Neurosciences group faculty members and graduate students will present and discuss ongoing research. Attendance will be mandatory for first- and second-year graduate students. Faculty, advanced graduate students, medical students, postdoctoral trainees, and other interested parties are encouraged to attend. (F,W,S) .
NEU 276.name: Neuroscience Research Rounds

NEU 277.class_description: An examination of the molecular and biochemical bases of drug and transmitter action. An examination of the molecular and biochemical bases of drug and transmitter action. The course is devoted to receptor mechanisms, neuropharmacology, and drug action on excitable tissues.
NEU 277.name: Neuropsychopharmacology

NEU 280.class_description: This intensive writing course offers graduate students in the neurosciences the opportunity to propose and defend an original research project. This intensive writing course offers graduate students in the neurosciences the opportunity to propose and defend an original research project. Students are required to select a research problem in the neurosciences and propose and experimental approach for solving it.
NEU 280.name: Minor Proposition
NEU 280.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: neurosciences PhD majors only; NE75, NE78 and NE80. (S/U grades only.

NEU 285.class_description: This course provides a methodological perspective on clinical trials. This course provides a methodological perspective on clinical trials. Topics will include ethics, design of Phase I–IV trials, randomization/blinding, bias, and sample-size power. Lectures will also cover “application” with eminent UC San Diego trialists describing conduct, design, and statistical issues of specific studies.
NEU 285.name: Clinical Trails: Issues and Dilemmas in Clinical Trials
NEU 285.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: medical or graduate student standing.

NEU 296.class_description: Independent study. Independent study. (S/U grades only.  (F,W,S) .
NEU 296.name: Neurosciences Research Rotation

NEU 299.class_description: Independent study. Independent study. (S/U grades only.  (F,W,S) .
NEU 299.name: Neurosciences Research

NEU 401.class_description: Provides opportunities for practical application of neurological skills to the understanding and treatment of a variety of clinical disorders of the nervous system. Provides opportunities for practical application of neurological skills to the understanding and treatment of a variety of clinical disorders of the nervous system.
NEU 401.name: Neurology General Clinical Selective Clerkship
NEU 401.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: successful completion of first two years of medical school. (F,W,S)

NEU 426.class_description: Subinterns are responsible for the primary care of hospitalized pediatric neurology patients under direct resident and attending physician supervision. Subinterns are responsible for the primary care of hospitalized pediatric neurology patients under direct resident and attending physician supervision. Students will perform procedures such as lumbar puncture and participate in night call, daily teaching round, neurology grand rounds, and journal clubs.
NEU 426.name: Subintern Pediatric Neurology
NEU 426.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: Neurology 401 or consent of instructor. (F,W,S)

NEU 427.class_description: The student will rotate through the general and subspecialty (stroke, epilepsy, headache, nerve, and muscle) neurology clinics based at UC San Diego Medical Center, Perlman, VAMC, and Children’s Hospital. The student will rotate through the general and subspecialty (stroke, epilepsy, headache, nerve, and muscle) neurology clinics based at UC San Diego Medical Center, Perlman, VAMC, and Children’s Hospital. There are lectures and clinical conferences.
NEU 427.name: Neurology Outpatient

NEU 496.class_description: Independent clinical study for medical students (S/U grades only. Independent clinical study for medical students (S/U grades only.  (F,W,S) .
NEU 496.name: Clinical Independent Study

NEU 500.class_description: Participation in the department teaching program is required of all students working toward a PhD. Participation in the department teaching program is required of all students working toward a PhD. In general, students are not expected to teach in the first year, but are required to serve as teaching assistants or tutors for one quarter at any time during their subsequent years of training. The amount of teaching required is equivalent to the duties expected of a 50 percent assistant for one quarter.
NEU 500.name: Apprenticeship Teaching
NEU 500.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: neurosciences graduate students. (S/U grades only. (F,W,S)

NEUG 240.class_description: This course teaches mathematical concepts in neuroscience to students inexperienced in computation and mathematics. This course teaches mathematical concepts in neuroscience to students inexperienced in computation and mathematics. Topics from linear algebra, calculus, information theory, digital signal processing, graph theory, and machine learning will be covered. An optional weekly tutorial will teach computing basics. Priority enrollment is given to PhD students. MS students may enroll with instructor approval. Calculus AB is recommended but not required.        .
NEUG 240.name: Mathematical Foundations for Computational Neuroscience

PHIL 1.class_description:
A general introduction to some of the fundamental questions, texts, and
				  methods of philosophy. A general introduction to some of the fundamental questions, texts, and
				  methods of philosophy. Multiple topics will be covered, and may include
				  the existence of God, the nature of mind and body, free will, ethics and
				  political philosophy, knowledge and skepticism..
PHIL 1.name: Introduction to Philosophy

PHIL 10.class_description: Basic concepts and techniques in both informal and formal logic and reasoning, including a discussion of argument, inference, proof, and common fallacies, and an introduction to the syntax, semantics, and proof method in sentential (propositional) logic. Basic concepts and techniques in both informal and formal logic and reasoning, including a discussion of argument, inference, proof, and common fallacies, and an introduction to the syntax, semantics, and proof method in sentential (propositional) logic. May be used to fulfill general-education requirements for Warren and Eleanor Roosevelt Colleges..
PHIL 10.name: Introduction to Logic

PHIL 100.class_description: A study of Socrates and/or Plato through major dialogues of Plato. A study of Socrates and/or Plato through major dialogues of Plato. Possible topics include the virtues and happiness; weakness of the will; political authority and democracy; the theory of Forms and sensible flux; immortality; relativism, skepticism, and knowledge. May be repeated for credit with change of content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 100.name: Plato
PHIL 100.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 101.class_description: A study of major issues in Aristotle’s works, such as the categories; form and matter; substance, essence, and accident; the soul; virtue, happiness, and politics. A study of major issues in Aristotle’s works, such as the categories; form and matter; substance, essence, and accident; the soul; virtue, happiness, and politics.
PHIL 101.name: Aristotle
PHIL 101.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 102.class_description: A study of selected texts from the main schools of Hellenistic philosophy—Stoicism, Epicureanism, and Skepticism. A study of selected texts from the main schools of Hellenistic philosophy—Stoicism, Epicureanism, and Skepticism.
PHIL 102.name: Hellenistic Philosophy
PHIL 102.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 105.class_description: The major writings of one or more of the philosophers associated with British empiricists—Locke, Cavendish, Berkeley, Hume, Shepherd, Cockburn, and Reid. The major writings of one or more of the philosophers associated with British empiricists—Locke, Cavendish, Berkeley, Hume, Shepherd, Cockburn, and Reid.  May be repeated for credit with change of content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 105.name: The Empiricists
PHIL 105.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 106.class_description: A study of selected portions of The Critique of Pure Reason and other theoretical writings and/or his major works in moral theory. A study of selected portions of The Critique of Pure Reason and other theoretical writings and/or his major works in moral theory. May be repeated for credit with change in content and approval of the instructor.
PHIL 106.name: Kant
PHIL 106.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 32 or 33 or 104 or 105 or 111 or 112 or consent of instructor.

PHIL 107.class_description: A study of one or more of Hegel’s major works, in particular, The Phenomenology of Spirit and The Philosophy of Right. A study of one or more of Hegel’s major works, in particular, The Phenomenology of Spirit and The Philosophy of Right. Readings and discussion may also include other figures in the Idealist tradition—such as Fichte, Hölderlin, and Schelling—and critics of the Idealist tradition—such as Marx and Kierkegaard.
PHIL 107.name: Hegel
PHIL 107.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 108.class_description: A study of one or more figures in nineteenth-century philosophy, such as Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, Marx, Emerson, Thoreau, Goldman, Luxemburg, James, and Mill. A study of one or more figures in nineteenth-century philosophy, such as Schopenhauer, Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, Marx, Emerson, Thoreau, Goldman, Luxemburg, James, and Mill.  The focus may be on particular figures or intellectual themes and traditions. May be repeated for credit with change of content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 108.name: Nineteenth-Century Philosophy
PHIL 108.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 109.class_description:
Central texts, figures, and traditions in
				  analytic philosophy. Central texts, figures, and traditions in
				  analytic philosophy. Figures may include Frege, Russell, Wittgenstein, Carnap, Moore, Austin, Quine, and Anscombe.  May be repeated for credit with change of content and
				  approval of the instructor.
PHIL 109.name: History of Analytic Philosophy
PHIL 109.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division			    standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 110.class_description: An examination of ancient Greek philosophy, focusing on major works of Plato and Aristotle. An examination of ancient Greek philosophy, focusing on major works of Plato and Aristotle. PHIL 10, PHIL 111, and PHIL 112 should be taken in order.
PHIL 110.name: History of Philosophy: Ancient
PHIL 110.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing and department stamp or consent of instructor.

PHIL 111.class_description: An examination of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century philosophy, focusing on major works of Descartes, Locke, and Hume. An examination of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century philosophy, focusing on major works of Descartes, Locke, and Hume. PHIL 110, PHIL 111, and PHIL 112 should be taken in order.
PHIL 111.name: History of Philosophy: Early Modern
PHIL 111.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 110, upper-division standing and department stamp or consent of instructor.

PHIL 112.class_description: An examination of late eighteenth and nineteenth-century philosophy, focusing on major works of Kant and Hegel. An examination of late eighteenth and nineteenth-century philosophy, focusing on major works of Kant and Hegel. PHIL 110, PHIL 111, and PHIL 112 should be taken in order.
PHIL 112.name: History of Philosophy: Late Modern
PHIL 112.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 111, upper-division standing and department stamp or consent of instructor.

PHIL 115.class_description: This course provides an introduction to the techniques of philosophical inquiry through detailed study of selected philosophical texts and through extensive training in philosophical writing based on those texts. This course provides an introduction to the techniques of philosophical inquiry through detailed study of selected philosophical texts and through extensive training in philosophical writing based on those texts. Enrollment limited and restricted to majors; must be taken for letter grade. May not be repeated for credit.
PHIL 115.name: Philosophical Methods Seminar
PHIL 115.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: open to philosophy majors only.

PHIL 12.class_description: Strategies of scientific inquiry: how elementary logic, statistical inference, and experimental design are integrated to evaluate hypotheses in the natural and social sciences. Strategies of scientific inquiry: how elementary logic, statistical inference, and experimental design are integrated to evaluate hypotheses in the natural and social sciences. May be used to fulfill general-education requirements for Marshall, Warren, and Eleanor Roosevelt Colleges..
PHIL 12.name: Scientific Reasoning

PHIL 120.class_description: The syntax, semantics, and proof-theory of first-order predicate logic with identity, emphasizing both conceptual issues and practical skills (e.g., criteria for logical truth, consistency, and validity; the application of logical methods to everyday as well as scientific reasoning). The syntax, semantics, and proof-theory of first-order predicate logic with identity, emphasizing both conceptual issues and practical skills (e.g., criteria for logical truth, consistency, and validity; the application of logical methods to everyday as well as scientific reasoning).
PHIL 120.name: Symbolic Logic I
PHIL 120.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 10 or consent of instructor.

PHIL 122.class_description: Topics vary from year to year. Topics vary from year to year. They include: Metalogic (Mathematical Logic), Modal Logic, Foundations of Logic, Foundations of Set Theory, Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorems, and others.
PHIL 122.name: Advanced Topics in Logic
PHIL 122.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 120 or consent of instructor.

PHIL 123.class_description: Philosophical issues underlying standard and nonstandard logics, the nature of logical knowledge, the relation between logic and mathematics, the revisability of logic, truth and logic, ontological commitment and ontological relativity, logical consequence, etc. Philosophical issues underlying standard and nonstandard logics, the nature of logical knowledge, the relation between logic and mathematics, the revisability of logic, truth and logic, ontological commitment and ontological relativity, logical consequence, etc. May be repeated for credit with change in content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 123.name: Philosophy of Logic
PHIL 123.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 120 or consent of instructor.

PHIL 124.class_description: The character of logical and mathematical truth and knowledge; the relations between logic and mathematics; the significance of Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem; Platonism, logicism, and more recent approaches. The character of logical and mathematical truth and knowledge; the relations between logic and mathematics; the significance of Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorem; Platonism, logicism, and more recent approaches.
PHIL 124.name: Philosophy of Mathematics
PHIL 124.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: PHIL 120 or consent of instructor.

PHIL 13.class_description: An inquiry into the nature of morality and its role in personal or social life by way of classical and/or contemporary works in ethics. An inquiry into the nature of morality and its role in personal or social life by way of classical and/or contemporary works in ethics. May be used to fulfill general-education requirements for Muir and Marshall Colleges..
PHIL 13.name: Introduction to Philosophy: Ethics

PHIL 130.class_description: Central problems in metaphysics, such as free will and determinism, the mind-body problem, personal identity, causation, primary and secondary qualities, the nature of universals, necessity, and identity. Central problems in metaphysics, such as free will and determinism, the mind-body problem, personal identity, causation, primary and secondary qualities, the nature of universals, necessity, and identity.
PHIL 130.name: Metaphysics
PHIL 130.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 131.class_description: An in-depth study of some central problem, figure, or tradition in metaphysics. An in-depth study of some central problem, figure, or tradition in metaphysics. May be repeated for credit with change of content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 131.name: Topics in Metaphysics
PHIL 131.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 132.class_description: Central problems in epistemology such as skepticism; a priori knowledge; knowledge of other minds; self-knowledge; the problem of induction; foundationalist, coherence, and causal theories of knowledge. Central problems in epistemology such as skepticism; a priori knowledge; knowledge of other minds; self-knowledge; the problem of induction; foundationalist, coherence, and causal theories of knowledge.
PHIL 132.name: Epistemology
PHIL 132.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 134.class_description: Examination of contemporary debates about meaning, reference, truth, and thought. Examination of contemporary debates about meaning, reference, truth, and thought. Topics include descriptional theories of reference, sense and reference, compositionality, truth, theories of meaning, vagueness, metaphor, and natural and formal languages.
PHIL 134.name: Philosophy of Language
PHIL 134.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 136.class_description: Different conceptions of the nature of mind and its relation to the physical world. Different conceptions of the nature of mind and its relation to the physical world. Topics include identity theories, functionalism, eliminative materialism, internalism and externalism, subjectivity, other minds, consciousness, self-knowledge, perception, memory, and imagination.
PHIL 136.name: Philosophy of Mind
PHIL 136.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 137.class_description: The nature of action and psychological explanation. The nature of action and psychological explanation. Topics include action individuation, reasons as causes, psychological laws, freedom and responsibility, weakness of will, self-deception, and the emotions.
PHIL 137.name: Moral Psychology
PHIL 137.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 138.class_description: A study of the nature and significance of responsibility. A study of the nature and significance of responsibility. Possible topics include freedom, determinism, and responsibility; moral luck; responsibility and reactive attitudes such as blame and forgiveness; responsibility and situationism; moral and criminal responsibility; responsibility and excuse; insanity and psychopathy, immaturity, addiction, provocation, and duress.
PHIL 138.name: Responsibility
PHIL 138.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 139.class_description: Social justice issues as they arise across the borders of nation-states. Social justice issues as they arise across the borders of nation-states. Topics may include nationalism and cosmopolitanism, theories of just war and just warfare, issues of migration and immigration, global distributive justice and fair trade, and international cooperation in the face of global problems such as climate change and human rights violations.
PHIL 139.name: Global Justice
PHIL 139.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 14.class_description:
A survey of central issues and figures in
				  the Western metaphysical tradition. A survey of central issues and figures in
				  the Western metaphysical tradition. Topics include the mind-body problem,
				  freedom and determinism, personal identity, appearance and reality, and
			    the existence of God.
PHIL 14.name: Introduction to Philosophy: The Nature of Reality

PHIL 140.class_description: Investigation into the nature of free will, including arguments for and against its compatibility with a scientific picture of the world and competing accounts of the metaphysics of free will. Investigation into the nature of free will, including arguments for and against its compatibility with a scientific picture of the world and competing accounts of the metaphysics of free will. Possible topics include disputes about the nature of free will; what it is for agents to cause actions; the nature of abilities or capacities to act; the relevance of neuroscience to accounts of free will; whether free will skepticism is a stable view; and experimental research on free will.
PHIL 140.name: Free Will
PHIL 140.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 145.class_description: Central problems in philosophy of science, such as the nature of confirmation and explanation, the nature of scientific revolutions and progress, the unity of science, and realism and antirealism. Central problems in philosophy of science, such as the nature of confirmation and explanation, the nature of scientific revolutions and progress, the unity of science, and realism and antirealism.
PHIL 145.name: Philosophy of Science
PHIL 145.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 146.class_description: Philosophical problems in the development of modern physics, such as the philosophy of space and time, the epistemology of geometry, the philosophical significance of Einstein’s theory of relativity, the interpretation of quantum mechanics, and the significance of modern cosmology. Philosophical problems in the development of modern physics, such as the philosophy of space and time, the epistemology of geometry, the philosophical significance of Einstein’s theory of relativity, the interpretation of quantum mechanics, and the significance of modern cosmology.
PHIL 146.name: Philosophy of Physics
PHIL 146.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 147.class_description: Philosophical problems in the biological sciences, such as the relation between biology and the physical sciences, the status and structure of evolutionary theory, and the role of biology in the social sciences. Philosophical problems in the biological sciences, such as the relation between biology and the physical sciences, the status and structure of evolutionary theory, and the role of biology in the social sciences.
PHIL 147.name: Philosophy of Biology
PHIL 147.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 148.class_description: Investigation of ethical and epistemological questions concerning our relationship to the environment. Investigation of ethical and epistemological questions concerning our relationship to the environment. Topics may include the value of nature, biodiversity, policy and science, and responsibility to future generations.
PHIL 148.name: Philosophy and the Environment
PHIL 148.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 149.class_description: Philosophical issues raised by psychology, including the nature of psychological explanation, the role of nature versus nurture, free will and determinism, and the unity of the person. Philosophical issues raised by psychology, including the nature of psychological explanation, the role of nature versus nurture, free will and determinism, and the unity of the person.
PHIL 149.name: Philosophy of Psychology
PHIL 149.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 15.class_description:
A study of the grounds and scope of human
				  knowledge, both commonsense and scientific, as portrayed in the competing
				  traditions of Continental rationalism, British empiricism, and contemporary
			    cognitive science. A study of the grounds and scope of human
				  knowledge, both commonsense and scientific, as portrayed in the competing
				  traditions of Continental rationalism, British empiricism, and contemporary
			    cognitive science.
PHIL 15.name: Introduction to Philosophy: Knowledge and Its Limits

PHIL 150.class_description:
Theoretical, empirical, methodological, and
				  philosophical issues at work in the cognitive sciences (e.g., psychology,
				  linguistics, neuroscience, artificial intelligence, and computer science),
				  concerning things such as mental representation, consciousness, rationality,
				  explanation, and nativism. Theoretical, empirical, methodological, and
				  philosophical issues at work in the cognitive sciences (e.g., psychology,
				  linguistics, neuroscience, artificial intelligence, and computer science),
				  concerning things such as mental representation, consciousness, rationality,
				  explanation, and nativism.
PHIL 150.name: Philosophy of the Cognitive Sciences
PHIL 150.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division				  standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 151.class_description: An introduction to elementary neuroanatomy and neurophysiology and an examination of theoretical issues in cognitive neuroscience and their implications for traditional philosophical conceptions of the relation between mind and body, perception, consciousness, understanding, emotion, and the self. An introduction to elementary neuroanatomy and neurophysiology and an examination of theoretical issues in cognitive neuroscience and their implications for traditional philosophical conceptions of the relation between mind and body, perception, consciousness, understanding, emotion, and the self.
PHIL 151.name: Philosophy of Neuroscience
PHIL 151.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 152.class_description: Philosophical issues of method and substance in the social sciences, such as causal and interpretive models of explanation, structuralism and methodological individualism, value neutrality, and relativism. Philosophical issues of method and substance in the social sciences, such as causal and interpretive models of explanation, structuralism and methodological individualism, value neutrality, and relativism.
PHIL 152.name: Philosophy of Social Science
PHIL 152.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 155.class_description: Introduction to Mexican philosophy with discussion of the work of such figures as Las Casas, Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, Vasconcelos, Uranga, Zea, Villoro, Dussel, Hierro, Lara, and Hurtado. Introduction to Mexican philosophy with discussion of the work of such figures as Las Casas, Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, Vasconcelos, Uranga, Zea, Villoro, Dussel, Hierro, Lara, and Hurtado. Topics may include historical movements, such as scholasticism, positivism, Mexican existentialism, and indigenous thought, as well as contemporary developments and the relationship to philosophy in the United States, Europe, and elsewhere..
PHIL 155.name: Mexican Philosophy

PHIL 156.class_description: Philosophical issues surrounding Latina/o/x peoples, which may include debates about the nature, function, and stability of this identity; social and political issues, such as immigration, economics, racial politics, and justice; phenomenological and existential accounts of latinidad; Latina feminism; and the relationship of these concerns to other philosophical traditions. Philosophical issues surrounding Latina/o/x peoples, which may include debates about the nature, function, and stability of this identity; social and political issues, such as immigration, economics, racial politics, and justice; phenomenological and existential accounts of latinidad; Latina feminism; and the relationship of these concerns to other philosophical traditions.
PHIL 156.name: Latinx Philosophy
PHIL 156.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 16.class_description: An introduction to philosophy which uses science fiction to make abstract philosophical problems vivid. An introduction to philosophy which uses science fiction to make abstract philosophical problems vivid. Science fiction themes may include time travel, teleportation, virtual reality, super-intelligent robots, futuristic utopias, and parallel universes. These scenarios raise philosophical questions about knowledge, reality, ethics, and the mind..
PHIL 16.name: Science Fiction and Philosophy

PHIL 160.class_description: Systematic and/or historical perspectives on central issues in ethical theory such as deontic, contractualist, and consequentialist conceptions of morality; rights and special obligations; the role of happiness and virtue in morality; moral conflict; ethical objectivity and relativism; and the rational authority of morality. Systematic and/or historical perspectives on central issues in ethical theory such as deontic, contractualist, and consequentialist conceptions of morality; rights and special obligations; the role of happiness and virtue in morality; moral conflict; ethical objectivity and relativism; and the rational authority of morality.
PHIL 160.name: Ethical Theory
PHIL 160.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 161.class_description: Central issues and texts in the history of ethics. Central issues and texts in the history of ethics. Subject matter can vary, ranging from one philosopher (e.g., Confucius, Aristotle,  Kant, or Mill) to a historical tradition (e.g., Greek ethics or the British moralists). May be repeated for credit with change in content and approval of instructor.
PHIL 161.name: Topics in the History of Ethics
PHIL 161.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 162.class_description: An examination of contemporary moral issues, such as abortion, euthanasia, war, affirmative action, and freedom of speech. An examination of contemporary moral issues, such as abortion, euthanasia, war, affirmative action, and freedom of speech.
PHIL 162.name: Contemporary Moral Issues
PHIL 162.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 163.class_description: Moral issues in medicine and the biological sciences, such as patient’s rights and physician’s responsibilities, abortion and euthanasia, the distribution of health care, experimentation, and genetic intervention. Moral issues in medicine and the biological sciences, such as patient’s rights and physician’s responsibilities, abortion and euthanasia, the distribution of health care, experimentation, and genetic intervention.
PHIL 163.name: Biomedical Ethics
PHIL 163.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 164.class_description: Philosophical issues involved in the development of modern science, the growth of technology, and control of the natural environment. Philosophical issues involved in the development of modern science, the growth of technology, and control of the natural environment. The interaction of science and technology with human nature and political and moral ideals.
PHIL 164.name: Technology and Human Values
PHIL 164.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 165.class_description: Examination of freedom and equality under the US Constitution, focusing on Supreme Court cases concerning discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic background, gender, undocumented status, wealth, and sexual orientation, and cases regarding contraceptives, abortion, interracial marriage, polygamy, and same-sex marriage. Examination of freedom and equality under the US Constitution, focusing on Supreme Court cases concerning discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic background, gender, undocumented status, wealth, and sexual orientation, and cases regarding contraceptives, abortion, interracial marriage, polygamy, and same-sex marriage.
PHIL 165.name: Freedom, Equality, and the Law
PHIL 165.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 166.class_description: Central issues about the justification, proper functions, and limits of the state through classic texts in the history of political philosophy by figures such as Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, and Arendt. Central issues about the justification, proper functions, and limits of the state through classic texts in the history of political philosophy by figures such as Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, and Arendt.
PHIL 166.name: Classics in Political Philosophy
PHIL 166.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 167.class_description: Different perspectives on central issues in contemporary political philosophy, such as the nature of state authority and political obligation, the limits of government and individual liberty, liberalism and its critics, equality and distributive justice. Different perspectives on central issues in contemporary political philosophy, such as the nature of state authority and political obligation, the limits of government and individual liberty, liberalism and its critics, equality and distributive justice.
PHIL 167.name: Contemporary Political Philosophy
PHIL 167.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 168.class_description: A study of issues in analytical jurisprudence such as the nature of law, the relation between law and morality, and the nature of legal interpretation and issues in normative jurisprudence such as the justification of punishment, paternalism and privacy, freedom of expression, and affirmative action. A study of issues in analytical jurisprudence such as the nature of law, the relation between law and morality, and the nature of legal interpretation and issues in normative jurisprudence such as the justification of punishment, paternalism and privacy, freedom of expression, and affirmative action.
PHIL 168.name: Philosophy of Law
PHIL 168.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 169.class_description: Philosophical examination of core concepts and theses in feminism, feminist philosophy, and critiques of traditional philosophical approaches to morality, politics, and science, from a feminist perspective. Philosophical examination of core concepts and theses in feminism, feminist philosophy, and critiques of traditional philosophical approaches to morality, politics, and science, from a feminist perspective. May also treat the historical development of feminist philosophy and its critiques. May be taken for credit two times with permission of instructor.
PHIL 169.name: Feminism and Philosophy
PHIL 169.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 170.class_description: A philosophical investigation of the topics of race and racism. A philosophical investigation of the topics of race and racism. The role of “race” in ordinary speech. The ethics of racial discourse. Anthropological and biological conceptions of race. The social and political significance of racial categories. Post-racialist conceptions of race.
PHIL 170.name: Philosophy and Race
PHIL 170.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 173.class_description: An in-depth exploration of an issue in bioethics. An in-depth exploration of an issue in bioethics. Topics will vary, and may include the ethics of genetic engineering, mental capacity and genuinely informed consent, the just distribution of health care, the ethics of geo-engineering, and the ethics of climate change and health. May be taken for credit two times.
PHIL 173.name: Topics in Bioethics
PHIL 173.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 174.class_description: A survey of ethical issues arising in the collection, storage, analysis, consolidation, and application of data. A survey of ethical issues arising in the collection, storage, analysis, consolidation, and application of data. Topics may include data as property and public resource, privacy and surveillance, data and discrimination, algorithms and fairness, and data regulation.
PHIL 174.name: Data Ethics
PHIL 174.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 175.class_description: Central issues in philosophical aesthetics such as the nature of art and aesthetic experience, the grounds of artistic interpretation and evaluation, artistic representation, and the role of the arts in education, culture, and politics. Central issues in philosophical aesthetics such as the nature of art and aesthetic experience, the grounds of artistic interpretation and evaluation, artistic representation, and the role of the arts in education, culture, and politics. May be taken for credit two times.
PHIL 175.name: Aesthetics
PHIL 175.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 177.class_description: A study of philosophical themes contained in selected fiction, drama, or poetry, and the philosophical issues that arise in the interpretation, appreciation, and criticism of literature. A study of philosophical themes contained in selected fiction, drama, or poetry, and the philosophical issues that arise in the interpretation, appreciation, and criticism of literature.
PHIL 177.name: Philosophy and Literature
PHIL 177.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 178.class_description: Careful, line-by-line translation of passages of intermediate difficulty from German philosophical texts, both classic (Kant, Fichte, Hegel, Schopenhauer) and contemporary (Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Habermas). Careful, line-by-line translation of passages of intermediate difficulty from German philosophical texts, both classic (Kant, Fichte, Hegel, Schopenhauer) and contemporary (Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Habermas).
PHIL 178.name: Topics in German Philosophy Translation—Intermediate
PHIL 178.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: consent of instructor and preauthorization.

PHIL 179.class_description: Continuation of PHIL 178 in the careful, line-by-line translation of passages of advanced difficulty from German philosophical texts, both classic (Kant, Fichte, Hegel, Schopenhauer) and contemporary (Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Habermas). Continuation of PHIL 178 in the careful, line-by-line translation of passages of advanced difficulty from German philosophical texts, both classic (Kant, Fichte, Hegel, Schopenhauer) and contemporary (Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Habermas). May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
PHIL 179.name: Topics in German Philosophy Translation—Advanced
PHIL 179.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: consent of instructor or completion of PHIL 178.

PHIL 180.class_description: An examination of the phenomenological tradition through the works of its major classical and/or contemporary representatives. An examination of the phenomenological tradition through the works of its major classical and/or contemporary representatives. Authors studied will vary and may include Brentano, Husserl, Heidegger, Stein, Merleau-Ponty, Levinas, and Irigaray.
PHIL 180.name: Phenomenology
PHIL 180.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

PHIL 181.class_description: Classical texts and issues of existentialism. Classical texts and issues of existentialism. Authors studied will vary and may include Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, Heidegger, Sartre, de Beauvoir, and Fanon.
PHIL 181.name: Existentialism
PHIL 181.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

This course emphasizes concepts with minimal mathematical formulation. Recommended preparation: college algebra.

Topics: Fourier series and integrals, special functions, initial and boundary value problems, Green’s functions; heat, Laplace and wave equations.

Module topics include MHD, waves, and the physics of locomotion and olfaction. May be coscheduled with Physics 216.
