PSYC 3.class_description: This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts of cognitive psychology. This course provides an introduction to the basic concepts of cognitive psychology. Topics include perception, attention, memory, language, and thought. The relation of cognitive psychology to cognitive science and to neuropsychology is also covered.
PSYC 3.name: General Psychology: Cognitive Foundations

PSYC 4.class_description: This course provides an introduction to behavioral psychology. This course provides an introduction to behavioral psychology. Topics include classical conditioning, operant conditioning, animal learning, and motivation and behavior modification.
PSYC 4.name: General Psychology: Behavioral Foundations

PSYC 500.class_description: Teaching practicum for students enrolled in graduate program in psychology. Teaching practicum for students enrolled in graduate program in psychology. Students who hold appointments as teaching assistants must enroll in this course. Minimum program requirement is for one four-unit course per year for four years. S/U grades only..
PSYC 500.name: Apprentice Teaching

PSYC 6.class_description: This course provides an introduction to social psychology. This course provides an introduction to social psychology. Topics may include emotion, aesthetics, behavioral medicine, person perception, attitudes and attitude change, and behavior in social organizations.
PSYC 6.name: General Psychology: Social Foundations

PSYC 60.class_description: This course provides an introduction to both descriptive and inferential statistics, core tools in the process of scientific discovery and the interpretation of research. This course provides an introduction to both descriptive and inferential statistics, core tools in the process of scientific discovery and the interpretation of research.
PSYC 60.name: Introduction to Statistics

PSYC 7.class_description: This course provides an introduction to theories and research results in developmental psychology, covering infancy through adulthood. This course provides an introduction to theories and research results in developmental psychology, covering infancy through adulthood.
PSYC 7.name: General Psychology: Developmental Foundations

PSYC 70.class_description: This course provides an overview of how to choose appropriate research methods for experimental and nonexperimental studies. This course provides an overview of how to choose appropriate research methods for experimental and nonexperimental studies. Topics may include classic experimental design and counterbalancing, statistical power, and causal inference in experimental and nonexperimental settings.
PSYC 70.name: Research Methods in Psychology

PSYC 71.class_description: This course provides hands-on research experience. This course provides hands-on research experience. Lecture topics will include experimental and nonexperimental designs, research ethics, data analysis, and causal inference. Students will design original research projects, collect and analyze data, and write a full APA-style report, including a brief literature review relevant to their design. This course builds on PSYC 70 by applying design principles to students’ own research questions and ideas.
PSYC 71.name: Laboratory in Psychological Research Methods

PSYC 81.class_description: This course provides students the opportunity to learn about the intricate relationship that exists between brain and behavior, as well as the evolutionary forces that shape this interaction. This course provides students the opportunity to learn about the intricate relationship that exists between brain and behavior, as well as the evolutionary forces that shape this interaction. Lectures for this course aim to introduce students to some of the best examples in the literature that highlight these issues, while a parallel component of the course aims to introduce students to performing research on the topic.
PSYC 81.name: Laboratory in Brain, Behavior, and Evolution
PSYC 81.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: COGS 14B or Math 11 or PSYC 60.

PSYC 87.class_description: The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Freshman Seminars are offered in all campus departments and undergraduate colleges, and topics vary from quarter to quarter. Enrollment is limited to fifteen to twenty students, with preference given to entering freshmen..
PSYC 87.name: Freshman Seminar

PSYC 90.class_description: This seminar introduces the various subdisciplines in psychology and their research methods, and also explores career and graduate school opportunities. This seminar introduces the various subdisciplines in psychology and their research methods, and also explores career and graduate school opportunities. This includes informal presentations by faculty, graduate students, and other professionals.
PSYC 90.name: Undergraduate Seminar

PSYC 93.class_description: Selected topics in the field of psychology. Selected topics in the field of psychology. May be repeated for credit as topics vary.
PSYC 93.name: Topics in Psychology

PSYC 99.class_description: Independent study or research under direction of a member of the faculty. Independent study or research under direction of a member of the faculty. May be taken up to three times for a maximum of twelve units.
PSYC 99.name: Independent Study
PSYC 99.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: lower-division standing, completion of at least thirty units of undergraduate study at UC San Diego with a minimum UC San Diego GPA of 3.0; completed and approved Special Studies form.

RELI 1.class_description: An introduction to key topics in the study of religion through the analysis of religious texts, artifacts, and/or practices. An introduction to key topics in the study of religion through the analysis of religious texts, artifacts, and/or practices. The intent is to develop basic strategies of interpretation for undertaking a critical, disciplined study of religion..
RELI 1.name: Introduction to Religion

RELI 101.class_description: This course provides an advanced introduction to assumptions and norms that shape the study of religion as an academic field; to significant debates within the field; and to tools and methods used for professional research within the field.. This course provides an advanced introduction to assumptions and norms that shape the study of religion as an academic field; to significant debates within the field; and to tools and methods used for professional research within the field..
RELI 101.name: Tools and Methods in the Study of Religion

RELI 134.class_description: Topical studies in the history of religion in American society, ranging from the Puritans to the New Age. Topical studies in the history of religion in American society, ranging from the Puritans to the New Age.
RELI 134.name: Topics in American Religion
RELI 134.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 141.class_description: This interdisciplinary course will explore the historical and theoretical relationship between public sphere and religion, particularly focusing on the manifestation of religious power, public ritual, and sacred theatricality in everyday spaces of life. This interdisciplinary course will explore the historical and theoretical relationship between public sphere and religion, particularly focusing on the manifestation of religious power, public ritual, and sacred theatricality in everyday spaces of life.
RELI 141.name: Public Sphere and Religion
RELI 141.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 143.class_description: This course explores religion as a system of bodily practices, rather than one of tenets or beliefs. This course explores religion as a system of bodily practices, rather than one of tenets or beliefs. How do day-to-day activities as well as significant rituals express and inform people’s religious lives? Why is doctrine an insufficient basis for understanding religion? May be taken up to three times as topics vary.
RELI 143.name: Topics in Performing Religion
RELI 143.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 144.class_description: Christianity frequently finds definition in contradistinction to an “Other” characterized as immoral, irrational, and malevolent. Christianity frequently finds definition in contradistinction to an “Other” characterized as immoral, irrational, and malevolent. This class investigates how devils and demons as constructions of the “Other” have contributed to Christianity’s growth and identity formation throughout history.
RELI 144.name: Devils and Demons in Christianity
RELI 144.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 145.class_description: This course will look at the relationship between information communication technologies (ICTs) and religion and how they have intersected or diverged in the course of history. This course will look at the relationship between information communication technologies (ICTs) and religion and how they have intersected or diverged in the course of history. We will look at both older and newer media, such as telegraph, radio, television, cassette tapes, Internet, and satellite, and how they have been used by groups like Evangelical, Catholic, or Islamist movements in proliferation and transformation of ideas, rituals, ideologies, values, and diverse forms of sociability.
RELI 145.name: Communication, Technology, and Religion
RELI 145.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 146.class_description: Topical studies in the religious beliefs, practices, and institutions of pre-Christian Europe and near East. Topical studies in the religious beliefs, practices, and institutions of pre-Christian Europe and near East. May be repeated for credit up to three times when topics vary.
RELI 146.name: Topics in the Religions of Antiquity
RELI 146.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 147.class_description: This course explores the history of how western Europe was converted from its indigenous pagan religions to the imported religion we know as Christianity. This course explores the history of how western Europe was converted from its indigenous pagan religions to the imported religion we know as Christianity. We will discuss conversion by choice and by force, partial or blended conversions, and the relationships between belief and culture.
RELI 147.name: Pagan Europe and Its Christian Aftermath
RELI 147.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 148.class_description: The course surveys women’s formal and informal roles and activities in a number of faiths, examining how women’s agency and activism may be constrained or fostered by religious ideologies and norms in various historical and political contexts. The course surveys women’s formal and informal roles and activities in a number of faiths, examining how women’s agency and activism may be constrained or fostered by religious ideologies and norms in various historical and political contexts. Examples are drawn from a range of male-centered religions (Islam, Judaism, Christianity, Buddhism), woman-centered religions (Sande, Afro-Brazilian, Z-ar Cult), and newly formed theologies (Womanist, Native American, and Mujerista; New Age feminist spiritualities).
RELI 148.name: Religion and Women’s Activisms
RELI 148.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 149.class_description: This course introduces the students to historical and social developments of Islam in the United States. This course introduces the students to historical and social developments of Islam in the United States. Tracing Islam back to the African slaves, the course examines various Muslim communities in the United States, with a focus on African American Muslims, especially Malcolm X.
RELI 149.name: Islam in America
RELI 149.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 150.class_description: The course is an introductory study of cinema and religion. The course is an introductory study of cinema and religion. It explores how cinema depicts religion and spiritual experience. A number of films will be studied to understand how cinematic and religious narratives and practices overlap and, at times, diverge in complex ways.
RELI 150.name: Religion and Cinema
RELI 150.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 151.class_description: This course explores intersections between religious discourse and ecological discourse by considering texts from both that treat the human world as irreducibly interconnected with more-than-human worlds of nature and “spirit.” Themes include the ambivalence of wildness; the critique of anthropocentrism (human-centeredness); and the question of how religious emphasis on “knowing (one’s) place” can create a sense of either human exceptionality, above nature, or embeddedness, within nature. This course explores intersections between religious discourse and ecological discourse by considering texts from both that treat the human world as irreducibly interconnected with more-than-human worlds of nature and “spirit.” Themes include the ambivalence of wildness; the critique of anthropocentrism (human-centeredness); and the question of how religious emphasis on “knowing (one’s) place” can create a sense of either human exceptionality, above nature, or embeddedness, within nature.
RELI 151.name: Deep Ecology: Knowing Place
RELI 151.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 153.class_description: This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among Hispanic Americans. This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among Hispanic Americans. The course examines changing religious traditions and ritual practices among Hispanic Americans with a focus on Catholicism and (evangelical) Protestantism.
RELI 153.name: Hispanic American Religions
RELI 153.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 154.class_description: This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among Asian Americans. This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among Asian Americans. Tracing back to the mid-nineteenth century, the course examines changing religious traditions and ritual practices among Asian American communities.
RELI 154.name: Asian American Religions
RELI 154.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 155.class_description: This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among African Americans. This course introduces students to historical and social developments of religion among African Americans. The course examines changing religious traditions and ritual practices among African Americans since slavery to the present era.
RELI 155.name: African American Religions
RELI 155.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing or consent of instructor.

RELI 157GS.class_description: This course examines Japanese religions by studying various traditions including Buddhism, Christianity, and Shintoism and their influence on Japanese culture such as anime and cinema. This course examines Japanese religions by studying various traditions including Buddhism, Christianity, and Shintoism and their influence on Japanese culture such as anime and cinema. Students must apply and be accepted into the Global Seminar Program..
RELI 157GS.name: Religion in Japan

RELI 158GS.class_description: This course looks at the relationship between literature and spirituality in Japan. This course looks at the relationship between literature and spirituality in Japan. The course explores this relationship in the works of Shusaku Endo, Hiromi Ito, Yasunari Kawabata, Haruki Murakami, and others. Students must apply and be accepted into the Global Seminar Program..
RELI 158GS.name: Japanese Literature and Spirituality

RELI 188.class_description: Students in this lecture will investigate important problems in the study of religion or the history of particular religions. Students in this lecture will investigate important problems in the study of religion or the history of particular religions. May be repeated for credit up to three times when topics vary.
RELI 188.name: Special Topics in Religion

RELI 189.class_description: This seminar requires the intensive analysis of critical problems in the study of religion or the history of particular religions. This seminar requires the intensive analysis of critical problems in the study of religion or the history of particular religions. May be repeated for credit up to three times when topics vary.
RELI 189.name: Seminar in Religion
RELI 189.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: upper-division standing; RELI 101 or consent of instructor.

RELI 192.class_description: The senior seminar is designed to allow senior undergraduates to meet with faculty members in a small group setting to explore an intellectual topic in religion at the upper-division level. The senior seminar is designed to allow senior undergraduates to meet with faculty members in a small group setting to explore an intellectual topic in religion at the upper-division level. Topics will vary from quarter to quarter. Senior seminars may be taken for credit up to four times, with a change in topic and permission of the department. Enrollment is limited to twenty students, with preference given to seniors..
RELI 192.name: Senior Seminar in Religion

RELI 196AH.class_description: First quarter of a two-quarter sequence of individualized, directed-research courses for majors in which students learn firsthand the processes and practices of scholarly research in the study of religion, culminating in the completion of a thesis and an oral presentation. First quarter of a two-quarter sequence of individualized, directed-research courses for majors in which students learn firsthand the processes and practices of scholarly research in the study of religion, culminating in the completion of a thesis and an oral presentation. Students may not receive credit for both RELI 196H and RELI 196AH.
RELI 196AH.name: Honors Thesis in Religion
RELI 196AH.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: RELI 101 (may be completed concurrently with the honors sequence)Department approval required for entry into the Honors Program.

RELI 196BH.class_description: Second quarter of a two-quarter sequence of individualized, directed-research courses for majors in which students learn firsthand the processes and practices of scholarly research in the study of religion, culminating in the completion of a thesis and an oral presentation. Second quarter of a two-quarter sequence of individualized, directed-research courses for majors in which students learn firsthand the processes and practices of scholarly research in the study of religion, culminating in the completion of a thesis and an oral presentation. Students may not receive credit for both RELI 196H and RELI 196BH.
RELI 196BH.name: Honors Thesis in Religion
