VIS 164.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 60. Open to art history and criticism, media, studio, and ICAM majors and photography minors.

VIS 165.class_description: Course explores both material and conceptual analog photography practices. Course explores both material and conceptual analog photography practices. Course will introduce the students to the history of chemical and ocular processes since the nineteenth century and their impact on image making. Students will learn basic black-and-white darkroom techniques, processing film, proofing, and printing. Course will conclude with a primer in the new photographic hybridity, bringing analog into the digital terrain. Students will be required to create a small portfolio of work. Program or materials fees may apply. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 165.name: Camera Techniques: Analog Futures
VIS 165.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 60. Open to art history and criticism, media, studio, and ICAM majors and photography minors.

VIS 167.class_description: The photograph is an empirical object. The photograph is an empirical object. This course will explore the use of photography as a tool to both understand and represent the world. Students will learn the history of the use of photography as evidence and as a tool of empirical knowledge. In a world where subjectivity is performed the students will be required to make a medium-sized work that engages the social in a creative way. Program or materials fees may apply. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 167.name: Social Engagement and Photography
VIS 167.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 164 or VIS 165. Open to media, studio, and ICAM majors and photography minors.

VIS 168.class_description: This course will explore photography as art and its long and complicated relationship with painting. This course will explore photography as art and its long and complicated relationship with painting. Students will learn and be encouraged to experiment with the medium formally and conceptually. From studio and lighting techniques to collage, montage, constructed realities, installations, and projections. Program or materials fees may apply. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 168.name: Pictorialism and Constructed Reality
VIS 168.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites:  VIS 164 or VIS 165. Open to media, studio, and ICAM majors and photography minors.

VIS 171.class_description: A digital image is not a film image, and this reality and its technological and conceptual implications are what this course will attempt to map out, exploring its possibilities and the massive overhaul of media aesthetics it implies. A digital image is not a film image, and this reality and its technological and conceptual implications are what this course will attempt to map out, exploring its possibilities and the massive overhaul of media aesthetics it implies. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 171.name: Digital Cinema—Theory and Production
VIS 171.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174. Open to media majors and film production minors only.

VIS 174.class_description: Video medium used both as production technology and as device to explore the fundamental character of filmmaking and time-based computer art practices. Video medium used both as production technology and as device to explore the fundamental character of filmmaking and time-based computer art practices. Students perform all aspects of production with attention to developing ideas and building analytical/critical skills. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 174.name: Media Sketchbook
VIS 174.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 70N. Open to media, studio, ICAM, and speculative design majors; and film production and speculative design minors.

VIS 175.class_description: The evolving aims and grammars of editing practice in film and digital media will be examined. The evolving aims and grammars of editing practice in film and digital media will be examined. These histories will create a context for exploring contemporary editing strategies. The production projects will be centered on digital editing practice. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 175.name: Editing—Theory and Production
VIS 175.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174. Open to media majors and film production minors.

VIS 176.class_description: A technical foundation and creative theoretical context for film production will be provided. A technical foundation and creative theoretical context for film production will be provided. Students will produce a short film with post-synchronized sounds and final mixed-track. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 176.name: 16mm Filmmaking
VIS 176.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174. Open to media majors and film production minors.

VIS 177.class_description: Script writing, reading, and analysis of traditional and experimental media productions. Script writing, reading, and analysis of traditional and experimental media productions. The emphasis will be on the structural character of the scripting process and its language. Students will write several short scripts along with analytical papers. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 177.name: Scripting Strategies
VIS 177.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174. Open to media majors and film production minors.

VIS 178.class_description: Sound design plays an increasing role in media production and has opened up new structural possibilities for narrative strategies. Sound design plays an increasing role in media production and has opened up new structural possibilities for narrative strategies. A critical and historical review of sound design and a production methodology component. Critical papers and soundtracks for short film projects will be required.  Two production-course limitation.
VIS 178.name: Sound—Theory and Production
VIS 178.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174. Open to media and speculative design majors and film production minors.

VIS 180A.class_description: Exploration of concepts in representational artworks by critically examining “found” vs. Exploration of concepts in representational artworks by critically examining “found” vs. “made” recorded material. Advanced film/video, photography, computing work. Issues of narrative and structure; attention to formal aspects of media work emphasized. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 180A.name: Documentary Evidence and the Construction of Authenticity in Current Media Practices
VIS 180A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 180B.class_description: Exploration of choices in invention, emphasizing “made” over “found.” Advanced film/video, photography, and computing. Exploration of choices in invention, emphasizing “made” over “found.” Advanced film/video, photography, and computing. Issues of narrative and structure, and formal aspects of media work emphasized. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 180B.name: Fiction and Allegory in Current Media Practices
VIS 180B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 181.class_description: Advanced course to gain sophisticated control of lighting and sound recording techniques with understanding of theoretical implications and interrelation between production values and subject matter. Advanced course to gain sophisticated control of lighting and sound recording techniques with understanding of theoretical implications and interrelation between production values and subject matter. Interactions between sound and image in various works in film, video, or installation. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 181.name: Sound and Lighting
VIS 181.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 182.class_description: Film/video editing and problems of editing from theoretical and practical points-of-view. Film/video editing and problems of editing from theoretical and practical points-of-view. Films and tapes analyzed on a frame-by-frame, shot-by-shot basis. Edit stock material and generate own materials for editing final project. Aesthetic and technical similarities/differences of film/video. Recommended preparation: VIS 175 Editing-Theory and Production strongly recommended. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 182.name: Advanced Editing
VIS 182.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 183A.class_description: Looks at the way that self-identity is reflected and produced through various media practices. Looks at the way that self-identity is reflected and produced through various media practices. Focus is on rhetorical strategies of biography and autobiography in media, comparing and contrasting these strategies with those drawn from related cultural forms. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 183A.name: Strategies of Self
VIS 183A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 183B.class_description: Looks at difference as it is reflected and constructed in various media practices. Looks at difference as it is reflected and constructed in various media practices. Course will examine a wide range of forms and genres such as ethnography, science fiction, crime narratives, documentary film, political drama, and animated shorts. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 183B.name: Strategies of Alterity
VIS 183B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 184.class_description: Film/video production will be framed through the script writing process, focusing on the problems of longer duration, density, and adaptation from other media. Film/video production will be framed through the script writing process, focusing on the problems of longer duration, density, and adaptation from other media. Students will both read and analyze both historical and contemporary scripts and produce a thirty- to sixty-minute script. Recommended preparation: VIS 177 Scripting Strategies. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 184.name: Advanced Scripting
VIS 184.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only.

VIS 185.class_description: Through instruction and discussion, the class will focus on guiding students through advanced production on a senior project. Through instruction and discussion, the class will focus on guiding students through advanced production on a senior project. Students will be expected to initiate and complete production on at least one portfolio-level project. May be taken for credit two times. Two production-course limitation.
VIS 185.name: Senior Media Projects
VIS 185.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: VIS 174 and two from VIS 164, 165, 171, 175, 176, 177, 178. Open to media majors only with senior standing.

VIS 190.class_description: This advanced course provides students with a unique immersive learning experience, based on design studio/atelier methods. This advanced course provides students with a unique immersive learning experience, based on design studio/atelier methods. This course develops students’ skills in the ideation, planning, and execution of complex individual and collaborative projects, including historical and contextual research, project ideation, planning and management, coordination of skills and responsibilities, iterative execution, and effective presentation.
VIS 190.name: Design Master Studio
VIS 190.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: senior standing and three courses: VIS 135, 142, and one course minimum from VIS 100, 101, 145A, or 161.

VIS 194S.class_description: This course will explore the path of the deliberately “unreal” in movies. This course will explore the path of the deliberately “unreal” in movies. Fantasy in film will be considered both in terms of its psychological manifestations and also in terms of imaginary worlds created in such willfully antirealistic genres as science fiction, horror, and musical films. Offered in Summer Session only. Program or materials fees may apply. May be taken for credit three times.
VIS 194S.name: Fantasy in Film

VIS 197.class_description: This advanced-level sequence coordinates three consecutive independent research courses to culminate in a completed thesis project in the third quarter of study. This advanced-level sequence coordinates three consecutive independent research courses to culminate in a completed thesis project in the third quarter of study. After the project’s public presentation, the faculty involved in the project will determine whether the student will graduate with departmental honors.
VIS 197.name: Media Honors Thesis
VIS 197.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: consent of instructor. Note: Requires a written proposal, 3.5 GPA in the major, prior consent from all involved, and approvals by the department chair and provost.

VIS 198.class_description: Directed group study on a topic or in a group field not included in regular department curriculum, by special arrangement with a faculty member. Directed group study on a topic or in a group field not included in regular department curriculum, by special arrangement with a faculty member.
VIS 198.name: Directed Group Study
VIS 198.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: consent of instructor. Note: Open only to upper-division students. Requires instructor’s, department chair’s, and provost’s approval. Pass/Not Pass grades only.

VIS 199.class_description: Independent reading, research, or creative work under direction of a faculty member. Independent reading, research, or creative work under direction of a faculty member.
VIS 199.name: Special Studies in the Visual Arts
VIS 199.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: consent of instructor. Note: Open only to upper-division students. Requires instructor’s, department chair’s, and provost’s approval. Pass/Not Pass grades only.

VIS 2.class_description: An introduction to art making utilizing the transaction between people, objects, situations, and media. An introduction to art making utilizing the transaction between people, objects, situations, and media. Includes both critical reflection on relevant aspects of modern and contemporary art practices (Marina Abramovic, Allen Kaprow, Adrian Piper, James Luna, Stelarc, Ron Athey, conceptual art, performance art, new media art, etc.  and practical experience in a variety of artistic exercises. This course is offered only one time each year.
VIS 2.name: Introduction to Art Making: Motion and Time-Based Art

VIS 20.class_description: This course examines history of Western art and architecture through such defining issues as the respective roles of tradition and innovation in the production and appreciation of art; the relation of art to its broader intellectual and historical contexts; and the changing concepts of the monument, the artist, meaning, style, and “art” itself. This course examines history of Western art and architecture through such defining issues as the respective roles of tradition and innovation in the production and appreciation of art; the relation of art to its broader intellectual and historical contexts; and the changing concepts of the monument, the artist, meaning, style, and “art” itself. Representative examples will be selected from different periods, ranging from Antiquity to Modern. Content will vary with the instructor.
VIS 20.name: Introduction to Art History

VIS 201.class_description: An exploration of a range of issues important on the contemporary critical scene through readings and writing assignments. An exploration of a range of issues important on the contemporary critical scene through readings and writing assignments. Topics will vary from year to year. (Required, MFA) .
VIS 201.name: Contemporary Critical Issues

VIS 202.class_description: A workshop/seminar devoted to a particular materials practice (e.g., media, painting, digital media, etc. A workshop/seminar devoted to a particular materials practice (e.g., media, painting, digital media, etc.  that engages with critical questions arising within that discipline. Content will vary from quarter to quarter. May be taken for credit two times. (Required, MFA) .
VIS 202.name: Art Practice

VIS 203.class_description: Workshop in which students engage in an extensive evaluation of one another’s ongoing work in preparation for either the First Year Review or MFA Review. Workshop in which students engage in an extensive evaluation of one another’s ongoing work in preparation for either the First Year Review or MFA Review. Offered every winter. May be taken for credit two times (Required, MFA).
VIS 203.name: Working Critique

VIS 204.class_description: Critical evaluation of the methods, practices, and disciplinary commitments of art history, encompassing both revisionist interventions of the late-twentieth century and earlier paradigms, in order to envision new discipline-specific and interdisciplinary directions for the future of art history and visual culture. Critical evaluation of the methods, practices, and disciplinary commitments of art history, encompassing both revisionist interventions of the late-twentieth century and earlier paradigms, in order to envision new discipline-specific and interdisciplinary directions for the future of art history and visual culture. (Required, PhD) .
VIS 204.name: Rethinking Art History

VIS 205.class_description: This seminar introduces art practice students to the graduate program in a workshop environment. This seminar introduces art practice students to the graduate program in a workshop environment. Emphasis is on the production of new work and on situating that work in relation to a larger art context. (Required, MFA) Offered every fall and required of all first-year MFA students.
VIS 205.name: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Art Practice

VIS 206.class_description: Seminar examines the interrelationship between theory and practice and the nature of artistic production as a form of research. Seminar examines the interrelationship between theory and practice and the nature of artistic production as a form of research.
VIS 206.name: Seminar in Art Practice Research
VIS 206.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: none. (Required for PhD in art practice concentration.

VIS 207.class_description: Workshop for PhD in Art Practice concentration students cotaught by PhD and MFA faculty offering extensive evaluation and critique of work. Workshop for PhD in Art Practice concentration students cotaught by PhD and MFA faculty offering extensive evaluation and critique of work. Intended to explore issues associated with artistic practice as a form of research in a university setting. Course is only applicable to VA76 and VA77 PhD programs. PhD students with a concentration in Art Practice my take VIS 207 each year until they qualify for candidacy..
VIS 207.name: Working Practice for Art Practice PhDs

VIS 209.class_description: This course includes research and discussion of the required thesis for MFA candidates in visual arts. This course includes research and discussion of the required thesis for MFA candidates in visual arts. Advancement to candidacy required. A draft of the MFA thesis paper is required to complete this course. (Required, MFA)..
VIS 209.name: Thesis Writing

VIS 211.class_description: This seminar addresses the space between narrative work generated from a factual base and that generated from a fictional one. This seminar addresses the space between narrative work generated from a factual base and that generated from a fictional one. Special attention will be given to discussing work that confounds the assumed gap between the two.
VIS 211.name: Fact and Fiction

VIS 212.class_description: This seminar will engage the space between personal and larger histories. This seminar will engage the space between personal and larger histories. How is one’s own past both intertwined with and determined by larger social histories? .
VIS 212.name: History and Memory

VIS 213.class_description: An exploration of what public space is and how it operates, with a view toward an expanded context for considering how public artwork can operate within it. An exploration of what public space is and how it operates, with a view toward an expanded context for considering how public artwork can operate within it. Included are areas such as mass media, activism, community action, computer networks, ecology, and alternative forums.
VIS 213.name: Public Space

VIS 215.class_description: Examines human interface as it informs or transforms how we read and participate in culture at large. Examines human interface as it informs or transforms how we read and participate in culture at large. Concepts such as subject/author/object relationships, abstraction, metaphor, analogy, visualization, and complexity are discussed to establish context.
VIS 215.name: Human Interface

VIS 216.class_description: An investigation of the world of artifacts (“works of art” and others) and how they function as agents of communication and modifiers of consciousness. An investigation of the world of artifacts (“works of art” and others) and how they function as agents of communication and modifiers of consciousness. Contemporary perspectives drawn from the fields of art theory, anthropology, contemporary art, and semiotics will be utilized.
VIS 216.name: The Object

VIS 217.class_description: A critical examination of the practices of self-defined communities (e.g., Bauhaus, Shaker, surrealists), which have attempted to change the social and spiritual quality of life by aesthetic means and of communities and subcultures defined by other means. A critical examination of the practices of self-defined communities (e.g., Bauhaus, Shaker, surrealists), which have attempted to change the social and spiritual quality of life by aesthetic means and of communities and subcultures defined by other means.
VIS 217.name: Communities and Subcultures

VIS 218N.class_description: Explores various strategies exhibited in a wide range of contemporary art practices engaging in the representation of personality, spirituality, and the physical self.. Explores various strategies exhibited in a wide range of contemporary art practices engaging in the representation of personality, spirituality, and the physical self..
VIS 218N.name: Imaging Selves and Others

VIS 219.class_description: Examines a topic of special interest to permanent and visiting faculty that is not addressed in the regular curriculum. Examines a topic of special interest to permanent and visiting faculty that is not addressed in the regular curriculum. As in other Art Practice/Theory seminars, students will both produce work and read and write critically about the topic. Topics will vary..
VIS 219.name: Special Topics in Art Practice/Theory

VIS 21A.class_description: Course offers a comparative and thematic approach to the artistic achievements of societies with widely divergent structures and political organizations from the ancient Americas to Africa and the Pacific Islands. Course offers a comparative and thematic approach to the artistic achievements of societies with widely divergent structures and political organizations from the ancient Americas to Africa and the Pacific Islands. Topics vary with the interests and expertise of instructor. Students may not receive credit for VIS 21 and VIS 21A.
VIS 21A.name: Introduction to the Art of the Americas or Africa and Oceania

VIS 21B.class_description: Survey of the major artistic trends of India, China, and Japan, taking a topical approach to important developments in artistic style and subject matter to highlight the art of specific cultures and religions. Survey of the major artistic trends of India, China, and Japan, taking a topical approach to important developments in artistic style and subject matter to highlight the art of specific cultures and religions. Students may not receive credit for VIS 21 and VIS 21B.
VIS 21B.name: Introduction to Asian Art

VIS 22.class_description: Wide-ranging survey introducing the key aspects of modern art and criticism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including neoclassicism, romanticism, realism, impressionism, postimpressionism, symbolism, fauvism, cubism, Dadaism and surrealism, abstract expressionism, minimalism, earth art, and conceptual art. Wide-ranging survey introducing the key aspects of modern art and criticism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including neoclassicism, romanticism, realism, impressionism, postimpressionism, symbolism, fauvism, cubism, Dadaism and surrealism, abstract expressionism, minimalism, earth art, and conceptual art.
VIS 22.name: Formations of Modern Art

VIS 23.class_description: This seminar introduces fundamentals of art historical practice such as descriptive and analytical writing, compiling annotated bibliographies with traditional and online resources, defining research topics, and writing project proposals. This seminar introduces fundamentals of art historical practice such as descriptive and analytical writing, compiling annotated bibliographies with traditional and online resources, defining research topics, and writing project proposals.
VIS 23.name: Information Technologies in Art History
VIS 23.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: none. Art history majors only.

VIS 234N.class_description: Critical and historical analysis of the institutions, social networks, and communicative media through which art is presented to its audiences. Critical and historical analysis of the institutions, social networks, and communicative media through which art is presented to its audiences. May also address theories of vision and visuality, spectatorship, public space, originality and reproduction, and public space.
VIS 234N.name: Frames of View

VIS 242.class_description: Critical study of the ways in which media (film, video, photography) and new media have been theorized. Critical study of the ways in which media (film, video, photography) and new media have been theorized. May be taught from a historical or comparative perspective or focus on a single topic or theorist.
VIS 242.name: Theories of Media and New Media

VIS 243.class_description: Study of the philosophical concepts of the function of art and visual culture and the criteria for its evaluation in diverse epochs and cultures. Study of the philosophical concepts of the function of art and visual culture and the criteria for its evaluation in diverse epochs and cultures. May be taught as an historical overview or comparative study or focus a single topic or theorist.
VIS 243.name: Aesthetic Theory

VIS 244.class_description: Investigations of one or more artist-theorists or movements, contemporary or historical, that put in issue the interface between theory and practice. Investigations of one or more artist-theorists or movements, contemporary or historical, that put in issue the interface between theory and practice. May also focus on a topic such as perspective, color, or narrative, or genre such as film or new media.
VIS 244.name: Studies in the Relationship of Theory and Practice

VIS 251.class_description: European art from late antiquity through the fourteenth century and the historical processes by which “medieval” art has been constructed as a category. European art from late antiquity through the fourteenth century and the historical processes by which “medieval” art has been constructed as a category. Topics may include devotional vision and the sacred image; medieval comic genres; neo-medievalism, fifteenth century to today. May be taken for credit three times.
VIS 251.name: Seminar in Medieval Art
VIS 251.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 252.class_description: Concentrates on the art of the Renaissance in Italy and the North through a changing series of topics, e.g., Vision and Composition in Perspective; The Sistine Chapel; Envisioning Jan Van Eyck; Renaissance Print Making; Leonardo da Vinci’s La Gioconda. Concentrates on the art of the Renaissance in Italy and the North through a changing series of topics, e.g., Vision and Composition in Perspective; The Sistine Chapel; Envisioning Jan Van Eyck; Renaissance Print Making; Leonardo da Vinci’s La Gioconda. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 252.name: Seminar in Renaissance Art
VIS 252.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 254.class_description: European and American Art, ca. European and American Art, ca. 1850 to 1960. Questions in Impressionism and Postimpressionism; The Cubist Revolution: Marcel Duchamp and the Anti-Formalist Tradition; American Modernism; Reckoning with Abstract Art; Issues of Dada and Surrealism; Soviet Avant-Gardes. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 254.name: Seminar in Modern Art
VIS 254.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 255.class_description: Thematic and critical discussions of recent US and international art, 1960s to the present. Thematic and critical discussions of recent US and international art, 1960s to the present. Art/Text; Mixed Media Practices; Conceptual Art; Art After Appropriation; Global Art at the Millennium; New Genres of Public Art; Mike Kelly and the Conceptual Vernacular: Art and Activism. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 255.name: Seminar in Contemporary Art
VIS 255.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 256.class_description: Topics in media (photography, film, video) and new media, contemporary or historical. Topics in media (photography, film, video) and new media, contemporary or historical. Coverage may be broad or addressed to a particular topic such as Film Remakes; Silent Cinema; Photography and Social Movements; The Language of New Media.
VIS 256.name: Seminar in Media and New Media
VIS 256.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 257.class_description: Topics relating to the art and civilizations of Pre-Columbian Mexico and Central America, either specifically art historical (such as iconographic, formal, and stylistic analysis) or encompassing a spectrum of interdisciplinary and cultural/historical problems. Topics relating to the art and civilizations of Pre-Columbian Mexico and Central America, either specifically art historical (such as iconographic, formal, and stylistic analysis) or encompassing a spectrum of interdisciplinary and cultural/historical problems. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 257.name: Seminar in Meso-American Art
VIS 257.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 258.class_description: Advanced studies in the secular and religious art traditions of China. Advanced studies in the secular and religious art traditions of China. From year to year, the seminar may focus on early China (Neolithic to the end of the T’ang dynasty), on later dynasties (Sung, Yuan, Ming) or on art of the People’s Republic. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 258.name: Seminar in Chinese Art
VIS 258.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 259.class_description: Historical and theoretical problems in the art of Mexico, Central, and South America art from the colonial period to today, as well as from the Hispanic traditions of the American Southwest. Historical and theoretical problems in the art of Mexico, Central, and South America art from the colonial period to today, as well as from the Hispanic traditions of the American Southwest. May be taken three times for credit.
VIS 259.name: Seminar in Latin American Art
VIS 259.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 260.class_description: Topics for this seminar concern Native American art history from ancient to contemporary times. Topics for this seminar concern Native American art history from ancient to contemporary times. Seminars may focus on archaeological and art historical approaches, philosophy and aesthetics, archaeoastronomy, and cultural contexts. Issues of globalization and transculturation may be examined as well. May be taken up to three times for credit.
VIS 260.name: Seminar in North American Indian Art
VIS 260.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: graduate standing or consent of instructor.

VIS 280.class_description: Practice in writing about art (both one’s own and others) accompanied by analysis of selected contemporary critical writings. Practice in writing about art (both one’s own and others) accompanied by analysis of selected contemporary critical writings.
VIS 280.name: Workshop in Critical Writing

VIS 281.class_description: Methodological investigation of and training in the practices of art museums, galleries, film and digital environments, public arts organizations, and the like. Methodological investigation of and training in the practices of art museums, galleries, film and digital environments, public arts organizations, and the like. Instruction by museum and gallery curators and opportunities for participation in ongoing programs at local art institutions.
VIS 281.name: Curatorial Practice

VIS 295.class_description: Individual research with the student’s individual faculty adviser in preparation for their comprehensive exhibitions for the MFA degree or qualifying exam for the PhD. Individual research with the student’s individual faculty adviser in preparation for their comprehensive exhibitions for the MFA degree or qualifying exam for the PhD. These units are intended to be with the chair of the student’s review committee. For the MFA degree, these units can only be taken after completing the First Year Review. (Required, MFA, PhD) .
VIS 295.name: Individual Studies for Graduate Students

VIS 298.class_description: Directed group study on specific topics not covered at present in the normal curriculum. Directed group study on specific topics not covered at present in the normal curriculum. Used as an experimental testing of courses that may be given regular course numbers if proved successful. Special arrangement with faculty member.
VIS 298.name: Directed Group Study

VIS 299.class_description: Graduate-level research under the direct guidance of a faculty member. Graduate-level research under the direct guidance of a faculty member.
VIS 299.name: Graduate Research

VIS 3.class_description: An introduction to art making that uses as its base the idea of the “conceptual.” The lecture exists as a bank of knowledge about various art world and nonart world conceptual plays. An introduction to art making that uses as its base the idea of the “conceptual.” The lecture exists as a bank of knowledge about various art world and nonart world conceptual plays. The studio section attempts to incorporate these ideas into individual and group projects using any “material.” This course is offered only one time each year.
VIS 3.name: Introduction to Art Making: Three-Dimensional Practices

VIS 30.class_description: Speculative design uses design methods to question and investigate material culture with critical creative purpose. Speculative design uses design methods to question and investigate material culture with critical creative purpose. This course provides a historical, theoretical, and methodological introduction to speculative design as a distinct program. Emphasis is tracing the integration of interdisciplinary intellectual and technical problems toward creative, unexpected propositions and prototypes.
VIS 30.name: Introduction to Speculative Design

VIS 41.class_description: This course provides a strong foundation in contemporary techniques of design communication, including: digital image editing, typography, vector-based illustration and diagramming, document layout, as well as basic digital video editing tools, and web-production formats. This course provides a strong foundation in contemporary techniques of design communication, including: digital image editing, typography, vector-based illustration and diagramming, document layout, as well as basic digital video editing tools, and web-production formats. Emphasis is on mastery of craft through iteration and presentation of multiple projects. Students may not receive credit for VIS 140 or ICAM 101 and VIS 41.
VIS 41.name: Design Communication

VIS 500.class_description: Apprentice teaching in undergraduate courses given by the Department of Visual Arts. Apprentice teaching in undergraduate courses given by the Department of Visual Arts. Graduate students are required to teach a minimum of one quarter (four units) within the department to fulfill degree requirements.
VIS 500.name: Apprentice Teaching

VIS 502.class_description: Training in teaching methods in the field of visual arts. Training in teaching methods in the field of visual arts. This course examines theoretical and practical communication and teaching techniques particularly appropriate to studio and production-style courses. Open to VA75, VA76, and VA77 major codes.
VIS 502.name: Graduate Teaching in Visual Arts

VIS 60.class_description: An in-depth exploration of the camera and image utilizing photographic digital technology. An in-depth exploration of the camera and image utilizing photographic digital technology. Emphasis is placed on developing fundamental control of the processes and materials through lectures, field, and lab experience. Basic discussion of image making included. Program or materials fees may apply.
VIS 60.name: Introduction to Digital Photography

VIS 70N.class_description: Operating as both a lecture and production course, this introductory class provides a technical foundation and theoretical context for all subsequent production-oriented film and video studies. Operating as both a lecture and production course, this introductory class provides a technical foundation and theoretical context for all subsequent production-oriented film and video studies. In the laboratory, the student will learn the basic skills necessary to initiate video production. Completion of Visual Arts 70N is necessary to obtain a media card. Program or materials fees may apply.
VIS 70N.name: Introduction to Media

VIS 80.class_description: A practical introduction to the studio art major and a conceptual introduction to how diverse strategies of art making are produced, analyzed, and critiqued. A practical introduction to the studio art major and a conceptual introduction to how diverse strategies of art making are produced, analyzed, and critiqued. Introduces historical and contemporary topics in painting, drawing, sculpture, installation, and performance art and field-based practices. Required for all studio majors and minors including transfer students. Must be taken in residence at UC San Diego.
VIS 80.name: Introduction to the Studio Major

VIS 84.class_description: A survey of the history and the art of the cinema. A survey of the history and the art of the cinema. The course will stress the origins of cinema and the contributions of the earliest filmmakers, including those of Europe, Russia, and the United States. This course is offered only one time each year. Program or materials fees may apply.
VIS 84.name: History of Film

VIS 87.class_description: The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. The Freshman Seminar Program is designed to provide new students with the opportunity to explore an intellectual topic with a faculty member in a small seminar setting. Freshman Seminars are offered in all campus departments and undergraduate colleges, and topics vary from quarter to quarter. Enrollment is limited to fifteen to twenty students with preference given to entering freshmen.
VIS 87.name: Freshman Seminar

WARR 1.class_description: This course facilitates academic success at a leading research university by helping students understand and embrace academic and curricular expectations, engage and map cocurricular opportunities, and strengthen critical thinking and organizational, interpersonal, and wellness skills. This course facilitates academic success at a leading research university by helping students understand and embrace academic and curricular expectations, engage and map cocurricular opportunities, and strengthen critical thinking and organizational, interpersonal, and wellness skills.
WARR 1.name: First Year Experience
WARR 1.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: open to Warren NFRS students only.

WARR 11A.class_description: Warren Scholars Seminar A allows students to develop and refine their expressive and analytical skills by exploring a topic from the perspective of a wide range of disciplines. Warren Scholars Seminar A allows students to develop and refine their expressive and analytical skills by exploring a topic from the perspective of a wide range of disciplines. The seminar emphasizes critical thinking, reading, and writing. The topic will vary each year. Letter grades only.
WARR 11A.name: Warren Scholars Seminar A
WARR 11A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: limited to first-year Warren College Honors Society students.

WARR 11B.class_description: Warren Scholars Seminar B allows students to further develop and refine their expressive and analytical skills by exploring a topic from the perspective of a wide range of disciplines. Warren Scholars Seminar B allows students to further develop and refine their expressive and analytical skills by exploring a topic from the perspective of a wide range of disciplines. The seminar emphasizes analytical thinking and argumentative writing. The topic will vary each year. Letter grades only.
WARR 11B.name: Warren Scholars Seminar B
WARR 11B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: WARR 11A; limited to first-year Warren College Honors Society students.

WARR 189.class_description: Students will gain a fundamental understanding of all stages of the writing process and will develop the necessary skills to serve as productive mentors for their peers. Students will gain a fundamental understanding of all stages of the writing process and will develop the necessary skills to serve as productive mentors for their peers.
WARR 189.name: Academic Mentoring and the Writing Process
WARR 189.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: permission of instructor is required to enroll.

WARR 2.class_description: This course facilitates academic success at a leading research university by helping students understand and embrace academic and curricular expectations, engage and map cocurricular opportunities, and strengthen critical thinking and organizational, interpersonal, and wellness skills. This course facilitates academic success at a leading research university by helping students understand and embrace academic and curricular expectations, engage and map cocurricular opportunities, and strengthen critical thinking and organizational, interpersonal, and wellness skills.
WARR 2.name: Transfer Year Experience
WARR 2.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: open to Warren College transfer students only.

WCWP 100.class_description: An upper-division workshop course in argumentation and research with particular attention to analyzing and constructing academic arguments. An upper-division workshop course in argumentation and research with particular attention to analyzing and constructing academic arguments. A course specially designed for and required of transfer students who enter Warren College through the TAG, IGETC, or another articulation agreement. The course must be taken for a letter grade to fulfill this requirement. Letter grades only.
WCWP 100.name: Academic Writing
WCWP 100.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: must be a Warren College student.

WCWP 10A.class_description: A seminar-style course in reading and writing required of all Warren College students. A seminar-style course in reading and writing required of all Warren College students. The course emphasizes argumentation and critical writing based on sources. Letter grades only.
WCWP 10A.name: The Writing Course A
WCWP 10A.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: satisfaction of the UC Entry Level Writing Requirement and must be a Warren College student. Junior/senior standing students need department approval prior to registering.

WCWP 10B.class_description: A seminar-style course in reading and writing required of all Warren College students who have completed WCWP 10A. A seminar-style course in reading and writing required of all Warren College students who have completed WCWP 10A. The course continues the emphasis on argumentation and critical writing based on sources. Letter grades only.
WCWP 10B.name: The Writing Course B
WCWP 10B.unrec_prereqs: Prerequisites: satisfaction of WCWP 10A and must be a Warren College student. Junior/senior standing students need departmental approval prior to registering.

WCWP 500.class_description: Consideration of pedagogical methods appropriate to undergraduate teaching in Warren College Writing courses, under the supervision of the program director. Consideration of pedagogical methods appropriate to undergraduate teaching in Warren College Writing courses, under the supervision of the program director. (S/U grade only.
WCWP 500.name: Apprentice Teaching in WCWP
